There was so much to unpack in this video and so many gold nuggets of knowledge.  What I knew of David Goggins coming in was that he was a paragon of discipline. I thought he was a master of taking control of his body when his mind and other parts of himself were not wanting to. This was evidenced by his time in the SEALS and the incredibly difficult endurance challenges he subscribed to.  After watching this video, I side with Dr. Huberman in saying that David Goggins is the paragon on internal dialogue and self mastery. The focus and pure internal mastery of the self is beyond remarkable, and I believe that, although he may not think it, that nugget of wisdom is what is going to give people motivation to cut off from mindless noise and get into their mind and bodies and really start having the conversations with themselves that are uncomfortable and painful to have.

So this dude, he went through struggles and hardships and then he saw an ad for navy seal and applied. They told him hes fat. So he went and flipped his life around, lost 300 pounds in 3 months. Later on set some world records  He has made impressive feats in his career but I don't like how he talks about his struggles as if nobody else on the face of this planet has ever been fat or abused or faced academic hardship, I just think people go through worse things in life and then become successful later in life; the difference is that he knows how to market himself and build a brand out of it  Also, he is not a happy, satisfied, relaxed or peaceful person. Eventually, his all-or-nothing mindset will take such a bad toll on him, and he thinks he's doing all these things and grinding right now so he will be able to maintain this lifestyle. Dude is in his 50s. 20 years later, he will be a fading legend. 50 years later someone will beat his records and have an even more inspirational story. So he is basically running towards and for nothing. This is the thing that bugs me how some men act like theyre indestructible like just chill ur a multimillionaire, what meaning is there in a life of suffering where you are constantly criticising yourself  The podcaster is just reinforcing him like ohhh doing hard things makes ur brain grow. And i was just thinking like these dudes have some hypocrisy like i bet they wouldnt clean their washroom, their toilets wash the dishes, cook their own meals, do their own laundry, etc and then they say do hard things, 'lean into the suck' where the suck is just running till your feet break

Itâ€™s how we grow.   And ADHD gets such a bad rap for being unfocused but itâ€™s not that â€” itâ€™s uncontrolled hyper focus to the things that drive us. We are wired to be machines, you just have to learn how to control it. Something doesnâ€™t interest you? Find a way to make it more challenging, make it a game. Make your brain work in your favor. self notes: 2:01:03 - 2:07:03  it was never about the running, he hates running the most yet he does it every day like he loves it. runs hundreds of miles for days. he lives in that state of suffering and pain because it is what gives him that willlpower to begin. the willpower itself comes from doing the things he hates (not difficult/hard things that he likes to do i.e lifting, but HATES to do), that self-confidence and willpower is built on that foundation and history of things he hates to do that hes done. and that work is hard and its ugly and not fun at all. but that allows him to be able to look at anyone in the eye and know that everything he's being real.  2:08:37 -   :  hes saying first go inwards, then action. he deeply respects his process of introspection, and fullt shutting out any distractions in order to hear his mind. he makes the painter analogy. hes working on the masterpiece that is himself in his head.  that suffering he chooses to go through. its for the voices in his head. its for the voices in his head that say he cant do it, its too hard, he wants to do something else, that wants to give up, that says hes not good enough. after enough of doing the things he doesnt want to do, those voices start being quiet and the "other" voice begins to win  he spends time in this introspection every single day. exploring the deepest darkest parts of himself. and its scary. hes extremely intentful with everything he does bc every single day he's looking inwards and seeing whats there, and faces it and acts accordingly. which is why so many people dont understand him, bc most never even begin to try look inward yet he spends every single day in the darkest corner of his mind and making it clean. and its also why hes not ashamed or afraid. he knows who he is  It's amazing that the public defines this person by his willpower and physical prowess. In my opinion, his strength comes from his constant and deep introspection. His self-awareness is remarkable especially when you factor in his disabilities

I heard about David Goggins two days ago and have followed Andrew Huberman for a  while now. Two days ago I found the podcast, "FORCE YOURSELF TO SUFFER: The Ultimate Willpower Guide - David Goggins Motivational Speech." My life changed and I am transformed and will never be the same person again. My two sons heard the same podcast and as soon as walking through the door this evening, no hello, only focused, and speaking to this miracle, mindset sealed, and viewing every moment with new eyes, all avenues open to suffer and live forever. Today, I suffered, banished fear, and told myself, if I fall, I will get up and suffer more.  Waiting, hoping for speedy death and peace, told my days were few and prisoner to one room, the ER, only with aid of a walker, and never without aid, I determined I am still alive to know suffering spoken two evening ago. Today, no walker, no wheelchair, in pain and walking, never allowing anyone to give me aid. In pain, no sleep, my body screaming for mercy, I ignored my thoughts, I moved, challenging my every thought, my every action and any nutrition that I allowed, dismissing all else. Purpose, finally the reason I am alive.  Thank you, Andrew Huberman, and David Goggins.

What a life changing episode! Two amazing human beings. I loved you honouring Goggins with the explanation of the anterior mid-cingulate cortex. That was special and so deeply appropriate and relevant.  This episode deserves 100M views though 19M and counting is not too shabby. Goggins dropping gems after gems, AND very single point he makes resonates with undeniable truth! P.S Just a reminder, this 1 year after the podcast was released - FIREEEE!

Discipline is stronger than motivation Goggins emphasized that you cannot rely on motivation; motivation comes and goes. What keeps you consistent is daily discipline, even when you donâ€™t feel like it.  The mind controls the body more than we think He explained that you often reach only about 40% of your capabilities before giving up. When you feel like you are done, you have actually used less than half of your potential.  The power of inner selfâ€‘talk Goggins repeatedly says: when fatigue or pressure increases, speak to yourself with clear and strong words. Turn your inner dialogue from negative to challenging and positive: â€œI can do this. Iâ€™m built for this. I will not stop.â€  Escaping excuses The discussion highlighted how many people justify their failure with their circumstances. Goggins: â€œYou are the only one responsible for your life. Write down all your excuses and start breaking them one by one.â€  Persistence matters more than perfection You do not need to be perfect or have a complete plan. Start with a small step, but never stop.  Understanding the brain under stress (Hubermanâ€™s input) Huberman explained how stress and pressure activate specific areas in the brain (the amygdala and the prefrontal cortex) and how training through discipline over time increases mental resilience.  Embracing pain as part of growth Goggins: â€œPain is not your enemy; it is your trainer.â€ Every time you face pain or exhaustion and keep going, your mind builds a new pathway for endurance.  A consistent daily routine He spoke about the importance of a strict daily routine that enforces discipline, such as: Waking up early â€“ intense workouts â€“ reviewing goals â€“ writing notes.

Here's exactly how he used writing to pass the ASVAB exams and lose over 100 pounds in 3.5 months to qualify for the Navy SEALs:   ---  1. He Got Ruthlessly Honest with Himself  Goggins looked in the mirror, didnâ€™t lie, and wrote down all his weaknessesâ€”mental, physical, emotional. He called it the Accountability Mirror. If he skipped a workout or ate badly, he wrote it down without excuses.  He also logged victories, like running an extra mile or passing a practice test.  Heâ€™d ask himself:  â€œDid I do everything I could today?â€  â€œWhere did I quit mentally?â€  â€œWhat needs to be better tomorrow?â€    This made him confront his habits, mindset, and laziness every single day.   ---  4. He Used Pain as Fuel  Whenever he felt unmotivated, he would read back his failuresâ€”everything he wrote down in his worst momentsâ€”and use that shame as fuel to keep going.   ---  This system helped him:  Lose 106 pounds in 3.5 months  Pass the ASVAB (Armed Services Vocational Aptitude Battery)  Qualify for SEAL training  Eventually become a Navy SEAL and ultramarathon runner    ---  Would you like me to create a daily template inspired by Gogginsâ€™ method that you can use digitally or print out?

My personal notes (NOT AI GENERATED):   ## 1. *Mindset: You vs You*  The biggest battle is between who you are and who you want to be.  To win, you need willpower and strong mental discipline.  It will suck, and it will continue to suck, but you have to want it and do it anyway.  Discomfort is part of the process, you must embrace it.  No course, video, or external resource will work if you donâ€™t truly want it.  You are responsible for putting in the work.  Have courage and passion to overcome your inner resistance.  Create your own reality.  ## 2. *Discipline and Willpower*  Discipline means doing the thing even when you donâ€™t want to.  â€œI donâ€™t want to do it... but I do it anyway.â€  Doing whatâ€™s hard repeatedly builds discipline.  Discipline is something you develop over time by being consistent.  When youâ€™re consistent, the anterior mid-cingulate cortex (aMCC) in your brain grows.  If you stop being consistent, it shrinks back.  â€œI do hate doing it, but I do it. Thatâ€™s discipline.â€  Eventually, your brain starts to believe you love doing it.  This is how willpower is built.  ## 3. *Know Who You Are*  Many people have FOMO because they donâ€™t know who they are.  Theyâ€™ve never experienced themselves.  Much of their potential remains locked upabout 70%.  People often lie about who they are to get admiration.  They want dopamine from othersâ€™ approval, so they pretend.  This is not sustainable.  Knowing who you are means not living to please others.  Even if it feels empty at times, donâ€™t compromise who you are.  You donâ€™t need others to motivate you.  You build who you are every day.  â€œAnd who I say I am, I am.â€  ## 4. *Your Mind and Inner Power*  Your brain depends on your internal monologue and dopamine intake.  Be mindful of both.  The right mentor or practitioner matters, donâ€™t just trust any therapist.  Understand yourself deeply.  This is when real ideas emerge.  According to Naval, self-reflection plus silence and clarity leads to infinite ideas.  Your unconscious mind is your superpower.  Learn to shut out noise, including internal and external distractions.  ## 5. *Mission and Passion*  Know what you love and do it.  No one else needs to pick up the boat for you.  Your mission should guide your actions.  Work is part of the mission. Relationships and friendships are also part of that path.  Passion gives you the energy to follow through.  Knowing your mission and committing to it, regardless of emotional state, is key.  Perfection is not a goal; it is the natural outcome of committing to your mission.  Know your identity.  Identity is not just knowledge or guidance, it defines your path.  You are not who others say you are.  You are who you say you are.  ## 6. *Failure and Growth*  Teach yourself how to fail.  Losing is part of the learning curve:  You will lose multiple times before you start to win consistently.  Losing builds neuroplasticity, your brain adapts and grows.  Failing helps remove memory blocks created by stress or anxiety.  The brain remembers better through experience.  Thatâ€™s why practice is essential.  ## 7. *Practice Strategy*  The ideal learning formula is 80% practice and 20% theory.  The more you practice, the more your brain retains.  Experience matters more than knowledge alone.  ## 8. *Health and Focus*  To support your mind, avoid the things that break focus and clarity:  - Avoid sugar. It crashes your thinking and leads to poor performance. - Eat well before intense work or exams, treat it like a gym session. - Use creatine (proven and sleep-approved). - Be consistent. - Stay passionate. - Make time to rest and recover, rest is not laziness. - Avoid social media, shallow connections, and external dopamine triggers. - Avoid noise from media.          "The field is my god."       ## 9. *The Learning Curve*  Learning takes time and repeated effort.  At first, progress is slow.  Memory improves as stress and anxiety go down.  Thereâ€™s no shortcut to the top, just consistent practice and self-awareness.

What I really like about David Goggins is that unlike most of the other influencers whatever he is saying he has proved by his own example. There is an abundant amount of information on how to make yourself motivated in work and the importance of work/life balance. But not everyone says that motivation and balance might make you better than average, but they will not make you the greatest. David on the other hand says that there is no motivation involved in what he is doing and there is no balance, he does everything necessary despite it being the most hated thing for him at that moment, and he is right. Everyone who succeeded in life spent an unhealthy amount of time on what they were doing. After some time there is no motivation involved, they just do it because they have to do it, and that's when they become greater than others.

Hi Andrew. I saw one of these podcasts so I had to log in on my phone so I could subscribe and like. I really enjoy your podcasts. I must say there was one in particular with David Goggins that really spoke to me. David was talking about how he learns that he'll have to look at it again and again. And that other people might look at it one time and know it. Please let David know this for me. I have never in my life heard anyone that can describe exactly how I learned that is how I learn. In junior college in geology class I would go to the geology lab every minute that there was of the day that it was open outside of time I was in other classes I was there until it closed. Going over the different rocks and studying the different material my teacher wasn't even there the other teacher was there that ran the lab and I would stay there from sunup to sundown I would leave for dinner and come back until they closed. And I would go home and study. There was someone else that lived in my neighborhood that didn't have a car and was in my class so I would give him a ride. I remember one time asking him about the upcoming Final and asked how he's studying was going and he just kind of giggled and he said that he didn't need to study. The short of it is we both got an A. One person didn't have to study just went over the material in class with everyone else and then there was me that spent every waking moment at the lab studying. I had to do that for every single test. I have the same exact learning that he does I just have to go over it again and again and again I always would describe it well the few times I've tried to explain it to people as this. " I totally understand something when I read it and when I hear it or when I see it". But then I completely forget it, immediately. So I must go over the material again and again and again. The result is once I know it I know it inside and out! And I'll bet have more insight to the material then the others. I never saw that as a negative. Let David know that it's not a negative. I call that a repeat learner. So we may have to repeat the material but then we know it better than anybody else. ğŸ™ğŸ‘ğŸ¤— two scriptures from the Bible to reference. One talks about renewing your mind and the other one talks about wisdom that it comes from God to all that ask for it. ğŸ‘ğŸ™ğŸ¤— I really enjoyed the podcast.

I've listened to DG off and on for years, clips, some full length podcasts. Bought his book 3 years ago,  still haven't read it. Was in a dark place, serious depression, life a mess, until March 26th '23, I took a step, very small. Committed to do this every day. The journey out hasn't been easy but DG, AH, others help tremendously. Almost a year ago I listened to a 13 minute clip of this on the Anterior mid cingulate cortex, which was amazing. Doing those small things you've put off doing, committing to be consistent, only increases your capacity to do more. Over the last 10 months, I've accomplished more than my last 10 years. Depression is gone. My encouragement to anyone where I was, start, commit to a very small step, make it doable in your mind, and stick to it. I'm 67, it's never too late.

I am amazed that David Goggins, through his trials and determination came to the exact same conclusion as St. Paul.    - *1 Corinthians 9:24-27* - "Do you not know that in a race all the runners run, but only one gets the prize? Run in such a way as to get the prize. Everyone who competes in the games goes into strict training. They do it to get a crown that will not last, but we do it to get a crown that will last forever. Therefore I do not run like someone running aimlessly; I do not fight like a boxer beating the air. No, I strike a blow to my body and make it my slave so that after I have preached to others, I myself will not be disqualified for the prize." This passage speaks directly to the discipline and hard work Goggins preaches, using the metaphor of an athlete's training for spiritual and personal discipline.  - *2 Timothy 4:7* - "I have fought the good fight, I have finished the race, I have kept the faith." This verse encapsulates the idea of perseverance through life's challenges, much like Goggins' narrative of overcoming his personal battles to achieve his goals.  - *Philippians 3:13-14* - "Brothers and sisters, I do not consider myself yet to have taken hold of it. But one thing I do: Forgetting what is behind and straining toward what is ahead, I press on toward the goal to win the prize for which God has called me heavenward in Christ Jesus." Here, Paul speaks of not dwelling on past failures but pushing forward, akin to Goggins' philosophy of not making excuses but moving forward.  - *1 Corinthians 15:10* - "But by the grace of God I am what I am, and his grace to me was not without effect. No, I worked harder than all of themâ€”yet not I, but the grace of God that was with me." This reflects the idea that while personal effort is crucial, there's also an acknowledgment of something beyond oneself (for Paul, it's grace; for Goggins, it could be interpreted as human potential or willpower) that enables extraordinary achievements.

As an addiction counselor (who is not in recovery) your teachings are the core in my psycho-education groups. Anxiety, trauma, cold exposure, discipline, etc..... I use all of your teachings in attempts to educate and motivate my clients to be aware and discover areas of themselves in need of more strength to fight addiction.

David, your words about pushing the limits of human willpower and breaking free from comfort zones resonate deeply with me â€“ but I want to add a perspective shaped by my own journey and insights. Itâ€™s not just about enduring lifeâ€™s hardships through discipline, but about discovering the depth we can uncover when our actions are aligned with a higher purpose.  Andrew, your research on willpower and the anterior cingulate cortex has given me profound insights into how consistent, intentional efforts can reshape our neural pathways. Iâ€™ve come to understand that willpower is not just a finite resource but something that can be cultivated through deliberate practice. This scientific understanding, combined with Davidâ€™s philosophy of â€œjust do it,â€ has helped me develop what I call the â€œSystem of Value-Oriented Continuity.â€  This system emphasizes the connection between action and a why. When we align our efforts with a higher goal â€“ for me, that goal is attaining Allahâ€™s pleasure through a clear spiritual mission, serving others, and personal self-development â€“ we transcend fleeting rewards. Central to this system is the purification of intention: acting not for fame, acceptance, or self-validation, but for the higher purpose of earning Allahâ€™s pleasure. Discipline, in this context, becomes not just bearable but meaningful. Pain and happiness are no longer goals but byproducts of a life driven by higher principles and fueled by willpower.  Andrew, your findings on building willpower align with my belief that life isnâ€™t about staying in a constant â€œfight mode.â€ Instead, itâ€™s about creating a system of continuous, value-driven action that balances effort with meaningful recovery. Discipline isnâ€™t an end in itself but a tool to embody our values. Mistakes, rather than setbacks, are opportunities for realignment. This system replaces fleeting motivation with consistency and chaos with intentional reflection.  Iâ€™ve also learned that recovery is as essential as effort. Iâ€™ve created anchors for myself by integrating moments of stillness and reflection into my day â€“ most notably through the five daily prayers (Salah), which serve as spiritual rituals and moments of mindfulness. Additionally, I wake up in the middle of the night for 10 minutes to perform Tahajjud (night prayer), starting with cold Wudhu (ablution). This action, though initially challenging, has become a cornerstone of my system. Choosing to do what is difficult strengthens my mind and willpower, aligning me with pure intentions and deepening my spiritual connection.  Most importantly, this system is driven by dedication to a higher purpose. For me, that purpose is aligning my actions with sincerity and the desire to attain Allahâ€™s pleasure. This includes fulfilling my responsibilities to myself, my family, my children, and society at large by contributing something meaningful. It is the realization that our days are limited and every moment is an opportunity to move closer to a greater goal. This awareness gives my actions spiritual depth and motivates me to act with intention and focus.  David, what I admire most about your approach is its radical simplicity â€“ the uncompromising â€œjust do it.â€ But I would add: this â€œdoingâ€ finds its greatest strength when it is grounded in inner sincerity and guided by values that truly transform us. Itâ€™s not just pain that shapes us â€“ itâ€™s the conscious decision to infuse that pain with meaning and purpose, bringing forth the inner diamond we all carry within ourselves.  Your discussion has reminded me that we are meant to transcend our limits. Not because we work harder than others, but because we can find depth in our actions that elevates us beyond ourselves. Thank you for sharing this message with the world. And thank you for reminding us that our greatest enemy isnâ€™t the circumstances we face but the inner resistance we must overcome.  â€“ Muharrem from Frankfurt/Germany

There was no carrot, no absence of reward, no cravings or troughs, only highs when talking about dopamine. It seemed like programming oneself to want nothing yet do something. It's like giving and expecting nothing, with no definition of external, just internal. It's like competing only with oneself's limitations in terms of its current state not for the sake of achieving something since reward should not be defined and also not because you want to prove something. What remains is hope, that no matter what the consequence of the action is as long as curiosity, in the form of Goggins's action, could be answered. Goggin is like a person that you cannot satisfy because he is always satisfied. That is a satisfaction that people nowadays often misinterpret due to our orientation to external wants. Now, Goggins spoke to the public and misinterpreted. I was confused as well in the first place because I was fed up with the fact that after craving, comes the reward and is oftentimes external. Somehow society put it that way and in Goggin's current state,  when I set aside the rewards that society places on him, he is still Goggins.   So for me, it's like curiosity to oneself. Knowing oneself and discovering the unknown. Same as with other great contributors in a lot of fields. Only the division of labor classifies it, but the algorithm stays the same.  Thanks for this wonderful podcast, which confirms a lot, though I hate saying philosophical. How I wish that to be more empirical in the name of neurology

If you have ADHD or ADD you got 30 minutes in by force lol... and you're debating to leave like me because you got the jist of the direction of this interview...   On the contrary, i don't think David is crazy and i resonate with his views on social media... it's all just noise on social media... or you can capitalize on it. Social media is a waste of time for absolutely the majority of people because it's all just blogs of materialistic lifestyles and very superficial. So it will only feed into negativity to be on there unless you have discipline and are calculated. Can you exploit social media for a gain? Or is it just useless likes and clicks in the midst of the time wasters on there. It's all as the famous line that was coined during the Roman Empire: Bread & Circuises. Useless food for a weak people to stay distracted and out of focus and purpose. I assume many of you learnt that during the planned-demic! At least i hope you did.   For myself, i came to the conclusion that discipline is paramount to anything in life... Whether it's prayer, physical activity, self education, or a balanced diet. To me, those which i listed above are a good foundation to start and if you have a hard time attaining those, then read a book i found 10-12 years ago called: The Slight Edge. It is the best book i read, which sparked my mind to begin building disciplines. And like David says, as soon as you turn it off, you get right back to square one. So you can not stop. You have to keep going. Even though "it sucks." We all know in our hearts that we have to keep going, and when you have that voice telling you in your head to stop, give up, lazy out, you fight it and you get a few steps further and the discipline engrains in your body a little bit more and a little bit more. Just as when you do those extra reps at the gym when you're tiring out.   I'll have to watch this in stages lol... i got to 45 minutes and I'm telling myself, i gotta do my prayers and head out to the gym! Lol...   I think many people will watch this video and resonate with David's experiences, though.   Thanks for the interview.

48 years old. Always had a hard time studying and learning. Always the one counted out in life, school, everything.  Relate on so many levels to this.  Goggins nails it thought; It is all on me/you to get it done. You want it, you have to do to it.  Forget what others say.   Also, I feel the frustration when you are trying to learn something and your spouse/partner just "gets it". Story of my life with my wife and I.  She just absorbs information.   Also....this just confirms what I already knew about myself, that no matter what we have accomplished, no matter what things we have done to make us look great.....inside, we are all still that child who was picked on, scared, told they wouldn't amount to anything. That's interesting that you get better basically by doing things that you kind maybe wanted to do but just can't seem to get into it, can't start or get going. IMO it's because you don't have that part of the brain developed, the neurons that are associated with that activity or that mentality are not connected. How to create connections- just like with learning- you start doing and repeating and with each time you do something new those connections between neurons get stronger and it becomes "easier" in a way to do it again because now, instead of having a blank space in that spot in the brain that deals with overcoming something, running, learning or whatever, now it has a connection and established pathway you can use and understand. It happened to me when i was a kid. I wanted to start running, but the day i planned on running it just didn't happen :D Because there is almost no connection in your brain with activities you haven't done before and no connections that deal with overcoming that same "blank state" where you can't seem to overcome something. But once you "just do it" a few times and start developing those habits/connections in the brain you become better at doing it.

Absolutely insightful from both of you. You both bring a positive message, you both bring what we need to hear.      Thing is with life is some can and do get themselves in sync but a significant number cannot master it. It is easier said than done and its as easy said as done, both statements are true.     Life is not easy and I mean just getting up each day and going through the the day. So many hurdles, big and small. Drive is needed always,   for without it we cannot even move. Just to take a shower or brush your teeth requires that all important drive/will.      I am not knocking what you both on what you say but some of us are stronger than others and some  get that light bulb moment/moments and are able to run with it, sadly there are others who push but keep falling down. They cannot seem to override that side of them for long enough to break that addiction/compulsion.  Even when/if you do manage to overide that weakness of will power and your sailing along nicely, holding steady, one little thing/big thing can kick you right back into that thing you fought so hard to get a grip of and the fight begins again.     Once your neuropathways have used something to help you cope, it is something your brain can push you into again and again.      I have been in and out of my addiction for years. I have mastered it over and over and sustained for years in between but  i know I have a weakness for it and therefore I have to show some sympathy/empathy for people who cannot seem to get a grip. One thing I do expect is some will power exersion. Never let go completely and if your addiction/compulsion is interfering with your ability to look after your children, then you really need to put your shoulder to the wheel and not allow yourself the luxury of falling right down.

Everyone that's ever succeed in life at anything has consciously used an alter-ego. And ego is a tool, not a master. However, it is important to master this tool, or else it will master you. Goggins happens to have used his ego to develop this alter-ego called Goggins. And so this explains why the only real way to succeed is to set your original self aside, and develop an alter-ego that will get you through anything you desire.

The will to live is the highest of highest motivators. That's the "stick". Facing fears. Facing near-death experiences, and feeling grateful that you went through it. And people seem to forget that food, shelter, and water is the carrot. You get to sleep tonight, you get to eat something tonight, you get to drink clean water today. Hence, the carrot is food. It's a treat. It is the reward. Today, people are taught that money is the rewardâ€”the carrot. Or the Likes on social media, or the vacation, or the "perfect man" for women who then break hearts because there's always another better thing out there.  We are so divided, not only as people today, but also divided from our true reality. Divided from biology itself. Divided from our basic needs. If you have a home, a car, a fan that blow cool air on you, a computer, internet, all types of food choices, and clean water, and still complain and let yourself fail at LIVING then you problem comes from your lack of awareness and perspective, as it is for everything. But not about others and or your future, but perspectives of the root of humankind. When you become obsessed in collecting that kind of data and roam the internet and books and so on about this, you'll find out so many things, your ethics, morals, values, priorities, principles; everything will change.

The thing with Goggins is that he found an addiction in his sports and uses it to escape. Therefore, he is running from his demon. And demons as in emotions. Coping with escapism. His trauma has him by the throat, and his only way to escape it is to fully distract himself in the moment by doing massive actions towards something physical. Which he chose to punish, rather than worship.   He found all the way possible to punish himself physically, and using his skeletons as loophole guilt to fuel his rage while doing his activities. So in essence, this is the exact same as a drug addict, who instead chose to do physical activities to escape his "demons", rather than drugs. And demons are a combination of memories, experiences, emotions, feelings, moments, and that little servant in his head keeps reminding him of something he doesn't want to hear, therefore he runs from it.  That voice only keeps replaying scenarios simply because he is asking for it to do so. Thing is, the day he realizes this and chooses to battle those said demons, only then things will change for him. But in consequence, he will have an ego death, and settle. Which is something he isn't ready for. Because finding the root is the battle. He's done this plenty of times, but I don't believe he has fully done it for specific skeletons in his closet.   Nevertheless, this explains his anger, rage, cussing, etc. it is unresolved trauma or anxiety. Whether it's his past or future. Meaning, it's something he's done or lived through, or it's something he wants to achieve, and hasn't found a solution yet, causing anxiety from spending time overthinking, leading to doubt, fears etc., hence; a form of demons. Maybe not for him, but this is for anyone else reading, too.

David Goggins, a man renowned for his relentless drive and indomitable will, has built a life on the pursuit of physical and mental mastery. His rigid discipline and unyielding determination have brought him great success, elevating him to the realm of the extraordinary.  Yet, within the recesses of his mind, a dark specter lingers â€“ the fear that one day, he may grow weary of the constant struggle and succumb to the seductive allure of surrender. This is not merely a concern for physical decline or loss of prowess. No, it cuts far deeper. It is the dread that the very essence of his being, the relentless drive that has propelled him to greatness, might falter and fade.  He imagines a grim future where his once-unshakable resolve crumbles, replaced by apathy and weakness. A future where the challenges he once conquered with ease become insurmountable, and the pain he once embraced as a testament to his fortitude becomes a crippling burden.  This vision haunts him, not because he doubts his strength, but because he knows all too well the fragility of human will. The knowledge that even the mightiest of warriors can be brought low by their own inner demons fuels his relentless pursuit of self-mastery, as he seeks to ensure that this nightmarish fate never comes to pass.

Few things I noted down in my own words. Just copy-pasting them here if anybody needed few notes (some things might be wrong):  - Anterior mid-cingulate cortex(every person has two of these on each side of the head) is a structure in brain that when people do something they donâ€™t want to do (itâ€™s not about adding more work, itâ€™s about adding work that you donâ€™t want to do) , it getâ€™s bigger.     - According to study, Anterior mid-cingulate cortex is smaller in obese people, and gets bigger when they diet.     - Itâ€™s larger in athletes.     - Itâ€™s especially larger in people who see themselves as challenged and overcome some challenge.     - In people that live longer lives, it keeps its size.     - In many context scientists are starting to see it as not only the will power but as the seat of the will to live.     - e.g. if a person hates chilled baths and does it anyway, the anterior mid-cingulate cortex grows but if the next day you enjoy it or donâ€™t do it out of fear or anything, it shrinks.         - anything you like to do isnâ€™t gonna enhance your anterior mid-cingulate cortex.     - not surprising to learn that itâ€™s strongly activated when we move our body when we donâ€™t want to. - David Goggins says everyday he too hates doing whatever he does, because those work are obviously hard and not just for normal people , for him too in the exact same person, he just does it repeatedly , just like Micheal Phelps said, that he hated practicing everyday, but still did it every day. He knew exactly his goal. The only difference is those who get it done, at the end consecutively doing it over time, win and everyone can. - I also came to know that David Goggins also doesnâ€™t consume mostly any content. - David Goggins says, thereâ€™s one thing he did wrong in his life : he used to please people for so many years and did it at the expense of himself. He says about himself in third person sturdily that he would never compromise David Goggins. (and now I think I too should see myself like that and protect myself that way) - To focus on his art/work, David Goggins says he cuts himself off from distractions, heâ€™ll do only 2 podcasts a year, heâ€™ll have his phone away, he says to be an artist, you donâ€™t want distractions( which i also thought), googling things to fix them wonâ€™t help very much . - David says first you have to teach yourself to fail , a lot of times, only then winning comes. Learn how to fail properly. You are always in for hell and your ass being handed to you when you start but that is mandatory to happen, but also only after that you are going to win. - He says - If you had the courage and the heart and the dedication and the mindset , everybody can go fuck themselves, I know , what I know, Iâ€™ve listened to myself enough to know , I know what I know. None of you can hear what Iâ€™m hearing. And thatâ€™s what people donâ€™t do enough of, they donâ€™t listen to their journey. They listen to everybody elseâ€™s shit.     - In short : Do what your heart says , having had enough learning about right and wrong , donâ€™t wait and hear otherâ€™s opinions. - Andrew says, a psychiatrist , Paul Conti whom he interviewed said â€œWe think that the forebrain, the part of our brain that creates strategy , etc. is the supercomputer. but no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no. The supercomputer of the brain is the unconscious mind. Itâ€™s the part of the mind thatâ€™s controlling almost everything. And most people donâ€™t do the work to understand how the unconscious mind is controlling them, which is a scary thing but filled with potential. - One more thing David said but Iâ€™m summarizing in short : Youâ€™ve go to reinvent yourself everyday.

This is from an Amazon reviewer who cured himself from schizophrenia and the steps he took to make it happen:  Paul Brown 5.0 out of 5 stars A resolve that reflects my own experience. Reviewed in Canada on February 13, 2022 Verified Purchase Amazing story. David Goggins shares his story of a personal transformation that is very powerful ( providing you can get beyond the many cursings he has to offer.) This man stumbled upon the very powerful laws of success, and used it to change his life and destiny within this world. I was diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia with delusions of grandeur, and for 7 years I was in and out hospitals: medicated, electroshocked and had no lasting improvement. The doctor later deemed me affected with "treatment resistant schizophrenia," and recommended my mom transfer me to a long-term care facility (she became my legal guardian as I was deemed a danger to myself.)  This took a turn for the worse and I almost offed myself after realizing the "reality" I believed and lived in for 7 years was a lie. The shock broke me, and my whole being called for death shortly after. But there in the process of committing my final act within this world, lighting struck and I came to myself. I saw this as the act of a coward, because I feared living in this world, hated and laughed at by everyone and everything. "Am I going to let them bully me to end myself? Not a chance. If they want me to go then let them do it with their own two hands. I will no longer run nor hide away in isolation." From that moment on I chose to take back my life from schizophrenia. I faced down every giant it sent to crush me with an unshakable resolve: the giant of extreme anxiety, the giants of fear, paranoia, delusion, the giant of intrusive and blasphemous thoughts, the giants of hallucinations (auditoy and visual,) the giants of insecurity, hate, resentment, persecutory delusions (the world was in me and every where I went people would reaÄ my mind commenting on my thoughts mostly laughing at the torment i was experiencing,) giant of distrust, the giant of loneliness (there was not a person in the world who i felt I could talk with and pain of that loneliness was unbearable.) I hid away in my room because it was "safe," but in this form of safety there was no freedom, there couldn't be any. But where the "pain" was, in the middle of that fire, the last place I wanted to be, was exactly where I needed to be: I had to willingly choose to make myself uncomfortable. Everyday from that moment of revelation, I left my room and talked with my mother and sisters, whom I thought were witches trying to kill me through witchcraft. I no longer waited for them to come into my room and greet me, instead when they got home, I went out and greeted them. I didn't do it because I felt like it, I did it because I didn't feel like it. I hated them for what I thought they did to me, and because I hated them I chose to embrace them. One inch at a time, one day at a time, I was able to move forward until today, I'm 100% free from all schizophrenia symptoms. I've been off meds for nearly 15 years now. I became an electrician and even passed my red seal and have been working full time in the trade. I just had my one year anniversary that I celebrated with a nurse that I married.  A co-worker loan me "Can't hurt me" because my story of recovering from schizophrenia, more specifically, how I did it reminded him of Goggins own mentality to get beyond his own insecurities, etc. Iâ€™ve never even heard the name Goggins until that point. But reading his story resonated with me because I too lived with that defeated self. I too held that "woe is me" victim mentality. I'd ask myself, "why me? What did I do to deserve this?" And I still suffered nonetheless. But when I shifted the question to, "WHY NOT ME?!" Again, the heavens opened up and a light came shining down touching my soul deep within (metaphorically speaking of course:) THAT'S THE QUESTION! It hit me so hard. For so long I couldn't see it. Why not me? Why do I deserve to be excluded from suffering? Babies are born into the world with all sorts of sickness and diseases and suffering, and here I'm crying, why me? I felt so ashamed I could barely lift my head. Nevertheless, this energized me to take on the entire world, and I did, and I won. I managed to accomplish what the doctors said to be impossible for someone who had schizophrenia as entrenched as i did: I overcame schizophrenia.  Reading this book made me realize why my co-worker asked me about Goggins. Many times it was as if I was hearing myself talk, word for word. It was incredible. It's a great book for the person who's tired to living defeated, whose back is against the wall and you've no way out. Within your darkest hour also lays your moment of opportunity to turn the tides of your struggle. Goggins tells us his story. I just shared a part of mine, and you've got your own to write with your life as you face down each obstacle trying to drag you under, and put them under your feet. It's our story, we determine the how it's told.

He survived a Nazi concentration camp and lost many of his relatives in the Holocaust. In a way, this psychology is described in the Logotherapy that Frankl created. I recommend everyone to read his books as well.  Even before Frankl, I admired Jack London's character, Martin Eden, and he does exactly the same thing.  And if you think, 'Well, that's a fictional character,' Jack London based this character on himself.

Goggins is a different influencer than any other I've seen. Lots of influencers really do preach quotes, live in social media where they hide their reality of their true selves. And us, consumers of media, really try to find EXTERNAL REASONS to temporarily motivate ourselves with podcasts, supplements, merchandise, etc. or do the opposite and feel depressed because other people enjoy life more than me.  But Gogginism is very INTERNAL, him writing his book is an EXAMPLE and EPITOME of an ordinary person who is the "bottom of the barrel." The overall MESSAGE of all his books is: "if I'm able to overcome the most stressful situations in life with the genetically worst cards dealt to me and still be on top, then any person ON EARTH has the capacity to do that as well."  I also found his advice to other people be unique: he advises to OTHER PEOPLE to not to do exactly what he is doing (running, going to be a Navy SEAL, etc.), but he influences people to find THEIR OWN challenges, weaknesses, strengths and to spend time ALONE to have those conversations within our minds. We need to identify and battle our OWN wars to stay on top of ourselves. BE THE BEST VERSION OF US ALL THE TIME.  Like in the matrix, the CHOICE is to either be our true selves or hide away and gain the attention of the social norm. Callusing the mind is really something you MUST BUILD, you're never born with it.  Here's how I'm applying this lesson to my life: I will openly express that I am a young, selfish, hot-headed college kid that is very stingy with money. I have a long track record of easily having a bad attitude with other people who push my buttons. Now I realize that I put myself around those people in order to try to "live the college life" which ends up backfiring. My challenge is that I have to find a way to not be selfish and control my emotions properly. However, my strengths is that I'm a hard-worker and although I'm cheap I really do find enjoyment in giving gifts to people I love. This is my hand I'm dealt with in my life.  Today, I started rucking light with 20lbs going 3.5 miles to get a benchmark. Now my motivation is just to do the same thing tomorrow, but maybe 0.10 miles farther. I'm also learning my own language Tagalog and reteaching my Nursing School material in preparation for next semester even though it's summer. I'm 58 a female and at one point I weighed 300 lbs. I'm only 5' tall! I have MS and have been in a nursing home 3 separate times. Man, I had to hear this to believe it. I was on my way to achievement so many times in my life, I had that will power, and I know how good it feels when it's on your side.. but I've been hit with setbacks (mostly self inflicted) like wrecking balls time and time again, until the last one broke me, and I found rock bottom. That was two months ago. I've spent all that time blaming and really hating myself, rotting away. I'm clawing my way back out of that hole today as I'm writing this comment. Just like David said, I've always known deep down what I had to do, but my will was so weak, I couldn't bring myself to do it. I was ready to give up and was hoping for death to put me out of my misery. I'm glad I escaped that spiral by the skin of my teeth, and I'm ready to try once again. I'm going to work on that will power, because that's the only thing that can lift the weight of my heavy soul. Thank you David and Andrew, thank you so much for this talk.

We live in a soft society.  We've all been cursed, as it were, with the problems of abundance.  Obesity.  Diabetes.  A cell phone for everyone.  Desk jobs.  We've lost the skills our ancestors had, which allowed them to wake up before dawn every day, crawl two hours through a mine tunnel just to clock in and start getting paid, and then crawl two miles back to get home to dinner.  Our ancestors would laugh in the face of the self pity our society has come to cherish and enshrine as gospel.  We think skipping a single meal is cruel and unusual.  Thank you, David Goggins for speaking real and cutting through the popular hurricane of entitlement, blame and excuses we are deluged with every day. So I'm intrigued by the anterior mid-cingulate cortex. Wondering if you can point me to any data about it and women in labor. I'm a midwife and I have been speaking of this "will-power" piece in regards to childbirth. There is a time in childbirth (mind you, only normal, physiological, unmedicated childbirth) where every women either thinks this or says it out loud: "I can't do this". This is usually at the end when in fact, the baby is not far from arriving. It's the cliff...every women needs to get to the cliff, think they can't go further, and then....they walk out in faith....and just do it. There is sooo much about this....I could go on forever, but I'm curious if you've come across any research about the anterior mid-cingular cortex and childbirth. I believe there may be some incredible growth of this during labor.

This is the episode that teaches the truth about life itself, the truth that is kept away from our ears in a "comfort-centric culture." It is not about pleasure or dopamine or reward, but about the pain of overcoming obstacles that we don't want to overcome and about the work that we would rather not do in order to grow and to learn. To do what we don't want to do brings us greater reward than those things that we want to do and are rewarded. This is the YouTube video and episode that will literally change the very operation of your life if you open your mind and accept the "suck" and the challenges of life...and not just run away from them when they appear.   I've needed this advice since I was a little kid suffering from depression and not wanting to be here in the first place. Had I heard this as a kid and understood the message, I would have taken every challenge on knowing that each challenge would suck...but doing it anyway because it just had to be done. And in the end, I would grow faster than anyone who wasn't willing to put in the work.

Really incredible message. I will say, though, that I don't understand how Dr. Huberman can say, or believe that "no one has ever died because of their emotions." I think I understand how we can get that impression with minor emotions, like when you're feeling sad or anxious one day, but there are endless examples of emotional states overtaking a person, such as they act harmfully or fatally---suicide (extreme depression or grief), homicide (anger), even heart attacks (from grief, sadness, stress), amongst many, many others.  I don't mean to make this a personal dig on Dr. Huberman (who has received plenty of digs already), but that's a prototypical masculine mindset (like the erroneous distinction between "reason" and emotion). It seems like such a statement can only be made by someone who hasn't experienced those emotional intensities---when individuals talk about struggling with emotional states, they aren't just biting their nails about small upsets; they're big.   At the same time, I so totally appreciate what Goggins is saying---I need to hear it!

Thank you Andrew,  I wanted to take a moment to express my gratitude for the incredible podcast episode you had with David Goggins. It was truly amazing and left a deep impact on me.   The concept that David shared about the inner work resonated deeply with me. It reminded me of the Internal Family Systems therapy developed by Mr. Schwartz. The idea of understanding and working with different parts of ourselves to achieve healing and growth is powerful and transformative.  Your podcast provided a platform for David to share his insights and experiences, and I appreciate how you facilitated the conversation with such thoughtfulness and depth. It was enlightening to hear David's perspective and how he applies these principles to his own journey of self-discovery and self-mastery.  Thank you for bringing such valuable content to your listeners and for continuously striving to explore important topics that inspire personal growth. I look forward to listening to more of your thought-provoking episodes in the future.  Gratefully, Patrick

As I listen to Andrew Huberman and David Goggins discuss building immense inner strength, I'm inspired to push myself harder and develop greater resilience. On most days...yes...this is my mindset. However, I need to remind myself to be cautious. As a workaholic with an addictive personality, I know I can easily fall into the trap of overworking and overachieving, which has led me down a dangerous path in the past.  Remember,  pain releases dopamine as well.  I've read many comments from others who, like me, are drawn to this mindset, and I understand the appeal. But I also know that I need to be careful not to let my enthusiasm for self-improvement become an excuse for neglecting my mental health and spiraling into pain chasing.  I've been down that road before, and it's a slippery slope. So, while I embrace the idea of building inner strength, I need to do so in a way that's balanced and sustainable for me. That means listening to my body and mind, taking rest days when I need them, and prioritizing my well-being alongside my goals. I'm committed to growth and self-improvement, but I also know that I need to do it in a way that honors my whole self, not just my drive and ambition. ğŸ™ğŸ¾â¤

First time hearing listening to David Goggins after hearing about him so much. I like his philosophy, but I do have some follow-up questions that maybe other people can help with.  Andrew asked Goggins if his life events were necessary to spur that initial change within him. Describes it as being "haunted" by his past...  I understand how this can work for someone in poor health or who's a dreg to society, but what does Goggins have to say to people who have had pretty good lives, i.e., not haunted by their past?  He says that the problem with most people is that "they don't want it," but it sounds like a haunted past is an essential ingredient to wanting it. Is it fair to demand that everyone else "wants it" as much as you do when they haven't endured the same hardship? Is it even possible for them to "want it" without any hardship in their lives?  As someone who's had a very fortunate life myself, I don't feel as though I need to spur any change. I am happy how I am, and I don't think life has to suck the way Goggins says. I don't feel like I'm missing anything in life, despite not pushing myself to the absolute limit like Goggins does.  So then Goggins' message, in my interpretation, really mostly applies to those who look at themselves and their lives, and they hate it.   I do also think he misrepresents how many people wake up and just immediately hate their lives. Yes, misery is relatable, and everyone has felt that at some point or another, but every day? No, I think that's just Goggins, and that's totally fine. He has all of the justification in the world to be the way he is and think the way he does. I just think his mindset, yeah, doesn't work for most people because they're people who are happy with their lives and don't feel the need to physically destroy themselves only to still not be enough.

Iâ€™ve been reflecting on David Gogginsâ€™s journey, and itâ€™s impossible not to admire his unparalleled achievements and sheer mental fortitude. Like many, I find his story deeply inspirational, especially as someone who has navigated the rough waters of childhood trauma myself. Gogginsâ€™s approach to life through ultra-endurance, mental discipline, and cognitive strategies is nothing short of extraordinary. Yet, this makes me ponder the complexities of human resilience and coping mechanisms.  My own path, much like his, initially took me down the route of pushing my physical and mental boundaries to their limits. For nearly two decades, Iâ€™ve been a personal trainer, nurturing a passion for running, lifting, and the pure joy of exercise. Inspired by how much I related to goggins, I found Ultraâ€¦ There was a time when the thrill of ultra-distances and solitary challenges of self-supported 100Km+ mountain missions were my ultimate testaments to dealing with my shit.  However, an intriguing shift occurred as I delved deeper into the emotional landscape of my traumas. It wasnâ€™t until I recently sought out assistance beyond my understanding and capabilities that I began to truly confront and mend the embedded scars of my past. This journey of emotional exploration and healing brought about a profound transformation. The relentless need to prove my endurance (and myself) through the next 100-miler, to meticulously plan my training year, gradually faded away. Now, if I run, itâ€™s for the sheer pleasure of itâ€”nothing more than a marathon distance, often just to revel in natureâ€™s embrace.  This transformation has led me to a place of contentment and peace I hadnâ€™t known before, revealing that the emotional conquest was the piece I was missing. Reading David Gogginsâ€™s books, I found his stories and challenges very relatable. And while I see him continuing his path with the same fervor as ever, I canâ€™t help but wonder about the â€˜what ifsâ€™. What if more exploration of the emotional dimensions of his life could offer him, or anyone for that matter, a different kind of peace and fulfillment?  Itâ€™s not my place to speculate on anyoneâ€™s journey, especially someone of David Gogginsâ€™s caliber. His accomplishments speak volumes, and if his method is what works for him, thatâ€™s admirable. Yet, from my own experience, addressing the emotional scars not only broadened my perspective but also alleviated the constant push for more, allowing me to find joy in simplicity and in moments I previously overlooked.  In the end, weâ€™re all walking our paths, facing our challenges, and hopefully finding our peace. Gogginsâ€™s story continues to inspire and always will.

I think what would help David to finally conquer his inner â€œdemonsâ€ is to reframe his â€œdemonsâ€ as his authentic emotional pain he suffered growing up through his own action or the action of others.    If he can view his â€œdemonsâ€ as his emotional pain of days gone by, he will gain compassion and love for the young and emotionally fragile man he once was and start healing the parts of his emotional mind that were hurt thus making him whole again. I believe that not everyone should be placed in front of a microphone and speak their mind. There are so many people that are hurting this already very damaged world and society, especially in the mess that the USA is in right now. But David Goggins is truly a godsend. The world needs more of him. I know some people will read this and think it's a stretch, but if we all had even a little of the will and discipline David has, imagine how much better things could be, for everyone. But only the selected few will hear messages like this and actually make it a living reality, so it becomes actual legimate proof for the rest. That it can be done, and if your drive is right, it WILL be done. I'm at a point where I have lost all hope in life. And I'm glad I did, because as David says, I also don't live off the hope factor anymore. As a woman, I spent years of my life pouring into people, situations, that completely drained me and left me broken, alone, and depressed. All because of hope. Because I hoped things would get better. Because I hoped this and that would happen. But life is brutal, and despite my best efforts to be good, I was dealt shit fucking cards. But I will rise from the ashes of everything reality burned for me. Videos like this really do change a person's life. I'm grateful that during a time where I find myself the most lonely and depressed I've ever been, there are people like David that remind you that despite the suck, the only way out is through it. This pain and the pain I have gone through in the past will mold me. I don't care to be successful, rich, and famous. All I want is to someday conquer my crippling depression and broken heart and say I fucking did it. I'm at the bottom of the pit right now, but someday I know I will look down at the pit, and I'll be strong enough to keep myself from falling in it. And next time, instead of expecting someone, especially someone I once loved more than life itself, to catch me... I will catch myself, take accountability, and fight through the suck. Instead of succumbing to it. I'm not waiting anymore, I'm not hoping anymore for someone to save me. I'm not waiting for my knight to come. I will be my own knight, my own warrior, because it truly is me versus me. I am beyond grateful for this video. It's come at a point where I needed it more than ever. I know this may sound dramatic to some, but this video saved my life. When all else has failed for me, I finally found someone who understands the suck but pushes on. It's what I've dreamt of doing, I just didn't know it was possible. But I'll see to it myself. I'm a depressed lazy piece of shit now, but someday I'll come back to this comment and see how far I've come. Thanks to anyone who read this through. I'll use this to hold myself accountable. Here's to embracing the suck and going through it instead of finding ways around it. We can do it. We can do anything we set our mind to. If you're in a pit, I pray you'll find your way out of it, too. It's not where you're meant to be.  Believe that. And just fucking do it. Although these messages seem more geared towards men, I hope David knows his messages work on women, too. Here's to being the best you can fucking be. Stay hard

If David read this, he would kill me: I follow David on IG, I read his first book. We're the same age, we served in the Navy around the same time, I did 20yrs, I think he did the same. I was not a SEAL. Listening to him talk about his past and present, I come to the conclusion that he needs  some form of counseling. I'm not a professional. But he needs to let go of the past and the idea that, to be better, he needs to be in this perpetual war with himself. If you no longer care about what others think of you, then sit back do yiur thing, relax and enjoy. Enjoy your wealth, your wife, and enjoy your life. I agree that we all need a little friction in our lives. But that's just doing things that make us feel good once we have completed them. Like getting out of bed earlier to get our cardio done for the day, getting our strength training done after work, weather that's at 6 or 7 pm., eating more sensible meals, reading every day. I agree with him on some that. I do it every day. But, running yourself to the ground, for whatever reason, is counter to reaching a state of mind that can help you be feel good about yourself. I also agree that we do need to stop feeling sorry for ourselves, but we also need to give ourselves credit where credit is due. Thanks for the  show Dr. Huberman.

Yo Andrew, thanks for having David on. Hey David...the thing you said about reading a page over and over again. I have a TBI from birth that caused Cerebral Palsy- which usually goes hand in hand with some form of ADHD. I have to do that too. I switched to audiobooks to help avoid this, but my internal monologue is often "louder" than what I'm trying to absorb. It's annoying, I'm 40 years old and some parts of my life, I really got the jump on. But in other things, man, I had a very hard time. I either have a very hard time explaining the whole ADHD aspect to people, or maybe they just have a hard time listening. But by you saying that, I feel like someone hears me. Thanks, man.

40:50 Some people may hate hearing this, but for the rest of us, this is exactly what we love to hear from you, man. Even though, I am doing fairly well, I've always wanted to focus more and get out of the ordinary, I hate the idea of a mediocre life. But for many years now I've been feeling like everything is foggy in my mind, I just sit and think way too much, I want to do more work and I refuse to go out, to just hang out, but I end up just sitting and thinking. Letting myself disconnect might just be the largest mistake I'm doing, because focusing for me has been ridiculously hard in the last few years. All my friends, even a few that are more successful than me, always tell me to go out and have more fun and I do, but I always end up regretting, struggling to get back in the game. The issue could be more complicated at the core, but regardless, I don't think there is any other solution than "staying hard" at all times. There can't be any magic solution, other than complete disconnection and ridiculously hard work.

I have been with my boyfriend for a year and a half. Last November 2023, I told him I always start stuff, then quit when they get harder, and it impacts my self esteem negatively. At the same time I started listening to Goggins.  1- Since then, I started running and lost 22 lbs. I started registering for races and I am increasing my personal records every damn week. 2- I also started doing calesthenics. I am starting to see muscles on my body I didn't know they existed. 3- I also started a podcast because of my fear of public speaking. 4- Finally, I started to learn ski. I was born and raised in Africa, never skiied or ice skated in my whole life. I fell numerous times the first day. I sticked to it, went back, took lessons, went back again, trained on my own. My plan is to ride a blue or black slope by the end of the winter season.  Why did I mention my boyfriend? Because monday, he came back from work and witnessed me walking on my hands for the first time, and he said I was a beast! I realized how listening to this Goggins mufker changed my life.  I am 44 yo and I realized how much I left on the table for so long because of fear.

If you were to speak about the disorder on Huberman Lab, people with OCD symptoms would be better equipped to understand their own brains and seek specialised therapy   2ï¸âƒ£ ERP is a type of therapy based on encouragement, facing your fears, becoming a stronger & more disciplined personality, and on virtuosity in noticing, naming, and feeling emotions. Â @Kal-EL_VoltaÂ  when you start self improvement you give yourself these goals you want to reach. Let's take "getting in shape" for an example. @JohnTavastianÂ  I got questions regarding ice baths. I believe he said that ice baths increase dopamine levels by 250%.  Wouldn't a spike in dopamine with ice baths lower the dopamine baseline when not engaging in ice baths, similar to drugs?  Wouldn't the spike in dopamine make the neurons reduce the amount of dopamine receptors to balance out the spike? Does high amounts of dopamine overwork and kill neurons? If not, why does meth or cocoaine seem to cause neuro decay?

Â @Kal-EL_VoltaÂ  I'm not smart enough to answer this question but this is what I know. Keep in mind I don't have sources to confirm. If I remember correctly Huberman one time talked about dopamine and how ice baths affected it. The ice bath doesn't affect the dopamine baseline but it does spike it and it's not a bad thing. There are 2 ways of getting dopamine. Easy and hard. Easy ways are things like social media and junk food. Things you don't need to put much effort into to get dopamine. These things are bad for your dopamine because you get it too easily and too much. Which increases your baseline and makes it harder to do actually difficult things. The hard ways to get dopamine are things like ice baths. They are good for you and they fix a messed up dopamine baseline to it's natural levels

@JohnTavastianÂ  awesome, thank you. It's good to know that hard work gets you the benefits of dopamine increase without affecting your baseline.   I want to see how I feel when my dopamine levels get to normal. I head it takes about 30-90 days. That's why I'm in the process of starting exercise and quitting weed, porn, and phone use.

I believe it can be a dangerous speach for some people: how do you say to someone with chronic insomnia, one week with no sleep at all, no way to process any kind of job (physically and mentaly) that they are just being "lazy"? The same could be applied for a person with major depression: are you going to tell them that they are lazy because they can't get off bed? I don't know... every psychiatric disorded I can think of defies the point of view delevoped in this podcast. However, I will try to let the message sink in and then see if I can change this perspective.
There is no carrot. There's only stick.

Man it resonated inside my head when he said : you're lazy,  you know exactly what you have to do... it just sucks to do it...  The realest thing i have ever heard. Most of the times we all know the anwsers to our problem we're just hiding from it and waiting for a magic pill or a miracle.

Maturing is realizing goggins isnâ€™t some super hero or something persevering through adversity. He is a tortured soul, stuck in a hell hole that he made himself, and he is going deeper and deeper just because he can.

I agree with everything expect doing hard things for no reason. Be disciplined for the life you want. Not random trivia. However, I understand Goggins purpose is studying the mind and giving everything out of himself. For him it makes sense. For you it doesn't. What do you want out of life? Okay now be disciplined toward that end. Grow and live outside your comfort zone toward that end. And have the discipline to be upbeat and not all Debby downer like David. Work doesn't make you a Debby downer unless you let it by not disciplining your mind.   And it is simple to know why those millionaires and billionaires feel like they are missing something. It is because they have NO goals.  Their goals are probably things they already know how to do. That's a dumb goal. Do it if you want but don't call it a goal. The thing that are missing is shooting for something they have no clue how to get.   Goggins might be the wisest guy that was never taught. It's truly unreal. Most people never figure out what he has by themselves.

I've gained many valuable insights from this discussion. I'm particularly fascinated by the idea of creating friction involved in hard work, especially in its relation to the functioning of the anterior mid-cingulate cortex. This leads me to wonder: could we speculate that recovered addicts may have larger anterior mid-cingulate cortices? As we all know, addiction recovery involves a significant and continuous effort to resist cravings even after one reaches a post-recovery phase. Thus, it seems plausible that the daily struggle faced by recovered addicts could lead to significant stimulation and potential growth in this brain region. If this is proven true, the finding will be counterintuitive as addiction is often associated with an assumption that individuals struggling with it have compromised brain regions related to willpower rather than enhanced ones.   On a separate note, Goggins seems to view "hacks" as shortcuts or attempts to circumvent hard work. To me, they're not mutually exclusive; that is, working smart using some "hacks" doesn't always prevent people from working hard. Those hacks can help people to reduce barriers preventing them from putting in the effort they need to. I think we need to be cautious of this type of messaging, as there are individuals who can genuinely benefit from certain tools or smart strategies to bring themselves to where they can actually work hard. For people living with significant barriers, you need tools as well as willpower. Ironically people who're accomplished despite challenging circumstances are quick to dismiss this reality.

I've only listened to the first half hour so far. I have a lot of respect for Goggins. I also noted his unhealthy core belief "I'm not smart" and wondered - based on who's definition? What's 'smart' mean? He's very intelligent. I couldn't help but wonder how his perspective might change if he started to notice when he said such things about himself and paused to change the narrative. We are all capable of intelligence and we each learn in our own way. Also hearing his expressed thoughts around how much running sucks. Again I wonder how he might feel if instead of waking up each day and thinking "running sucks", he applied gratitude "I am so grateful that I get to run each day and stay this fit and on the top of my game". I'm a big believer in conscious language shifts and I would love to see Goggins find more joy in his life, he deserves it. Also - the revising one page over and over till it's rote-learned - I used to think I had to learn that way too and eventually realised actually if I push past the perfectionism and read through it, even if it doesn't make sense, and continue to consume multiple resources on the same topic that actually the terms keep recurring, explained in slightly different ways and contexts, and learning this way was more fun. Goggins if you ever read this, I would encourage you to give it a try. Just keep powering through multiple resources on the same topic till it makes sense. Also helps with critical thinking when sources vary slightly. Also, if you do read this, thank you for the mental cookie jar analogy from your book. It's been an integral piece of my personal growth to understand, and I refer to it in my own books!

I have severe complex trauma and dissociative identity disorder. There have been times in life I channelled Goggins. I do mental & physical therapy on myself everyday. It's when I starter listening to Goggins & Peterson I shifted gear. No one gives a damn if you suffer and die alone. This is it. This is life. I am recovering from a broken leg which scared me because I lost a lot of muscle during the recovery.  I've been doing painful workouts that I DO NOT want to do but I do them anyway.  Thanks for letting me know this is what discipline is all about.

I hear David's main point: "It's up to you".   While that's useful, I do feel that there is this pressure to be "great" and I feel like this is why people like Andrew become famous because they send this message that it is possible for everyone to be great. I think everyone can be better, but not everyone can be great. Otherwise, great wouldn't be a thing.   I bow to the self-discipline and determination that people have to change. Being someone who has had to go through a huge change in my life through personal will, I also wanted to become great. Over time, it has become a burden that never stopped haunting me. Making me feel like nothing will ever be enough. I do feel like it has become a sort of obsession to "be great", especially in the Western world. Especially in North America.  You don't HAVE to be great. That is the one thing I'd say that both Andrew and David get stuck on. I understand it's very hard to detach your worth from what you do, but again... you don't HAVE to be great. If being great is your only focus, were you really great at something, or just great at being great? How did you treat your neighbour today? Did you open the door for someone today? How about a smile at a stranger? A helping hand to someone who you know can't do anything for you?   I think this collective obsession with being great stems from a place of scarcity that society emposes on us, in one way or another.   Let's all help each other become great... I think that's where true meaning lies.   Thanks for reading!

Could it become enjoyable to do hard things, and not grow that area anymore because of purposefully seeking hard things to gain the benefits?
