Is there willpower in choosing your words wisely? Comparing Rick Rubin podcast interview to this one Rickâ€™s intentionality, level of consciousness, and words chosen wisely from the mind of a professional creator vs professional survivor of life can be measured in Hz to carry more positive impact on influencing the world. While I like some aspects of this podcast there is a point where your own energy as the host becomes submissive to the domination of Davidâ€™s thoughts, words, and energy that you begin to narrow focus on validating his belief system to the degree that you put him on a pedestal and then start using science to support his belief system as the way people need to be for a successful or worthy life. Thereâ€™s a fine line between high performance and sociopathy, and after spending decades of my life in the field with people at the world class level, that type if dominance over others using pain as reward resulted in damage to or loss of life in others from a place of self and other hatred. Living your life perceiving yourself or others as pieces of shit may be effective for increasing oneâ€™s willpower and bank account but itâ€™s not healthy for oneâ€™s nervous system because itâ€™s an addiction to the hormones of stress that keeps us tethered to the lower emotions of anger, shame, self and other hatred. Itâ€™s useful to the military for warfighting but not something that should be put on a pedestal because it can be measured via sound waves and light frequencies in Hz as dissonance (more and more effort and energy that creates patterns of opposing forces). The opposing forces are already here in this natural environment. We evolve to harness our brain, body, conscious, and energy so that we are not stuck in states of survival and being a victim of our environment or circumstance. Yet this podcast is riddled by a victimhood energy that was harnessed for war and became the operating system that is the comfort zone David perceives himself to reign over. Clearly success can come from operating this way especially in survival and military or emergency situations but that is not the reflection of an evolving brain in balance or growing in a way that itâ€™s designed for the human potential and a potential which flows positive impact outwards without also flowing equally destructive and opposing forces. David is in battle with himself 24/7 and heâ€™s developed the willpower to survive his operating system but that is not a brain at its highest potential or an expression of human excellence that elevates the world or lives around it. Itâ€™s surviving and dominating and I wish you realized that and could have helped him grow and reorganize his operating system using neurobiology and neuroscience advancements vs reinforcing and putting the imbalance on a pedestal. I am a service connected disabled military veteran and a world record holder athlete, and my experience comes from combat wounded research expeditions as a team leader as specialty care provider technologist and inventor along with Pentagon best practices in resilience and rehabilitation to peak performance from a whole body/whole human perspective.

This was so amazing. Until it wasn't. I love everything this podcast stands for (that I have heard so far). I listened to over two hours of this podcast thinking David Goggins is beyond fucking amazing. He ONLY finds his worth when he creates and OWNS it. That's fucking incredible and true. Until you stop there......  I'm so thankful the relationship question was asked. I happened to have the same beliefs when it comes to relationships. That being said....... Goggins response of "he makes sure everyone he cares for is well taken care of so they LEAVE HIM THE FUCK ALONE...." that comment completely trumped the entire podcast. He has no one. I stopped it right there. And I'm not sure I will ever listen again. Life sucks. It will always suck and I appreciate the realness of that entire dialog. But he is SOLELY living for himself. Teaching other people to ALWAYS be as self-centered as he needs himself to be to LIVE his life to what he believes is its FULLEST will NOT EVER get another individual to where they need to be. Life is about figuring out how to overcome/ process/ recover/grieve/defeat failure. But it will NOT move in any kind of direction without success in some form of love for someone (any form of life) else. It's no wonder so many people go back to their addiction. Some aspect or form of a person's life HAS to be worth living for. Not just living to feel confident in a room full Rich intelligent self absorbed people.

â€œOne does not become enlightened by imagining figures of light, but by making the darkness conscious. The latter procedure, however, is disagreeable and therefore not popular.â€ -Carl Jung. Others have preached similar messages than David, but not to his level of "madness," for lack of words. What he embodies is particularly special. I will say that, as a woman, I resonate with what he says, but I apply what he says differently. Iâ€™m not ever going to go through Seal training (duh) and I'm not going to be running 30 miles a day; I donâ€™t want to and donâ€™t feel bad about that. I am accessing this new level of mental fortitude by going immensely deep in the â€œdungeon,â€ as Goggins refers to it, and cleaning it out. This requires MASSIVE amounts of pain that have caused me to break down on nearly every level; to the point where death was far more favorable. But I NEVER fucking gave up on myself. I pulled myself out of the fucking muck and mire of life and came out of it as a ravenous fucking animal. The trauma that I felt for SO long did not get the best of me. I REFUSE to be a victim. We cannot "heal" or become fortresses if refuse to access the fucking DEPTHS of our pain. We have to SIT in our pain. We have to become one with it and accept it. We cannot just numb our pain w/ substances or anything else, for that matter; anything can be used as a crutch. We cannot heal if we refuse to listen to the "negative"/ constructive feedback of others. We need to call out OUR OWN SHIT. We need to take accountability of how fucking shitty we can be and DO SOMETHING ABOUT IT. I have learned that I will never compromise my truth for anyone or anything. Really appreciating this conversation for a lot of different reasons. I have some thoughts and opinions I feel the need to express and a lot of questions for Goggins, some of which I donâ€™t believe have definitive answers, and might be a bit rhetorical, but in any case I feel the need to ask them anyway.   So, from the outside looking in it seems as though Goggins has found some level of joy in the willful engagement between his Self and friction, or tension; that Goggins has found a certain peace in the misery of reality; maybe this Goggins even finds some joy in the internal praise, that is given by himself, for his accomplishments in the conquest to overcome and persevere in the face of adversity. It feels as though maybe that is the carrot on the stick. That despite the sticks use in consistently assaulting him and his persons. That maybe there is actually a carrot at the end of the stick that is yet to be seen?  It makes me wonder if the Goggins that we know, who learns to overcome and persevere in the face of adversity, would find same passion in moving that battle of will internally? I guess I wonder, would that not be the ultimate adversity for a world that seems to have been conquered externally? If it is true that the Goggins we know, has found success in his achievements through his approach, is it not also true that this same Goggins, to some degree, can find and recognize patterns of systems that work seamlessly to give you consistent and reproducible results?   Is it not also true that this Goggins is consistently building his kingdom from The base up, daily? If that is the case, then is it not also true that this Goggins can find fluidity in these daily practices, finding ease in the certain knowns and unknowns of that process? If this Goggins has found practical use of repetition and patterns - practices, then is it not the case that this Goggins can find a greater speed and momentum in the execution of those practices? That thereâ€™s always more space and time available in its infinite state? Putting down block after block in this routine way, at an almost inconceivable speed? Is it not also true, that in this very way this Goggins would in fact always be keeping what works and discarding what doesnâ€™t? And in that, can it be assumed that some of this Goggins truth would be in his ability to refine this process infinitely with ease?   That makes me also wonder this; is it also the case that a truth of this Goggins is to gain access to, what seems like, inaccessible spaces? If this is the case, then I wonder if it would be that this Goggins might eventually use that same force of will to find and explore the basis of this Goggins - His - internal framework? His emotions, his thought process, his awareness, his empathy, his sympathy, his anger, his compassion, his passion, is love, his joy, his peace, etc. and fortify those same things in the way that this Goggins has fortified his will. Is it not that this Goggins is in fact the life long study of his Self? Is it not the case that his every piece is a crucial component to that study? Is not his health, his function, his consistency, his effortless ease of efficiency, not also a focus of practice in the study of that Goggins?  It seems also that a part of this Goggins experience is to unveil his inner potential from the seat of his will.(?) And if that is true, then would it not be the case that unveiling and developing the reoccurrence of these states: of paralleling emotions, thought processes, awareness, empathy, sympathy, etc. would be another unveiling of itâ€™s own? Is not the fluid use of these, with the momentum of action, not also a goal? Would it not benefit that Goggins to have all hands available in the battle of his own mind? all internal enemies turned allies? all the parts taken care of, with that same care to family, so that the true Goggins can do his work?   Is it not like that of an internal kingdom being worked with? Would it not benefit that Goggins - You - to also develop a more fluid and direct form of communication with these internal voices? If there is a two way dialogue happening, is it not the case that these voices are just as flexible in their approach of communication as you are? Does that not also mean that you can develop and change the relationship with these inner voices? As to see them as allies, albeit from the sounds of it maybe not always so helpful, but friends nonetheless; as to make peace with them, as to collaborate, as to cooperate, as to find a level of communication that is heard as helpful suggestions in favor of this kingdom you are building in spite of their resistance - this kingdom of heart. Is it not also the case that in working with people that seem to be unworkable, unchangeable, immovable, that you would be in some way working with an external representation of your own internal voices?   As to see that there is change available to even the most stubborn of forces? That you have the potential to move this immovable force through your work in the study of you - in the study of your Self. Is it not also the case then that these inner voices could to take on a synthesized version of the characteristics of all of the mentors that you didnâ€™t have, all of the support you werenâ€™t given, by working with these individuals in this way? Is it not the case that these voices are in fact modular pieces of a whole You, that they too have a place at the seat of your Self? Can they not also learn to drive as you have? Can they not also be allowed to take on you as the mentors that theyâ€™ve never had? Is it not symbiotic in this way?  If it is to be said that the mind is malleable, flexible, and potentially limitless, then could not those same very violently opposed voices be worked with in changing their tone, delivery, and the brashness of their communication? Are they not as capable as you are in their own ability to adapt, make changes, and grow from the experiences that have been given?   If what you are expressing here is that the mind is ultimately the only real adversary? Then would it not benefit this Goggins to have access to all of the components of it, if not only just to see how the systems of them work? If not only to just admire how complex they are, and how little we know of them?  I also wonder if as you enter the dungeon of your psyche daily, as you have established yourself also as an occupant of this dungeon, is it also the case that you have built a barracks there, a home of sorts? And I wonder if that is the case, do you not also roam the other areas of your kingdom? Are you not also the people that occupy this space? Are you not also the judge, jury, and executioner at the gallows of your own thoughts? The civilians that occupy the space of you? The trades and markets, the shops and crafters, the goods and grains, the libraries, the theaters, the sounds, the wind, the animals and critters, the lakes and rivers. Do you not also dine at the seat of your own table, built with your own hands, and enjoy a meal from the fruits of your own labor, to nourish yourself for the unseen battles of tomorrow? And do you not also rest in the bed that you have made? This kingdom that you maintain daily, is it not also your sanctuary?  In thinking about this particular Goggins, I envision that even if this imaginary kingdom were to be just a rooted tree, that this Goggins would have it a home that could be occupied by any wayward soul. That its purpose and meaning would be practical and available to their awareness almost immediately, with no real question about what is what. That its intention would be displayed in its function, things being as they are, for what they are, and for what they are needed for, and everything in its right place.   I seem to also imagine that the paths you may have forged leading to this place, although not readily accessible, can be taught and learned. I imagine you as a guide in that way. To others who have wandered astray, or are finding a way. I see also you building tools in much of the same way, adding to the knowledge of what is possible and the effectiveness around that possibility. I also see this compression and denseness in that gravity of your practice. A sort of reforming of yourself as opposed to a stretched expansion of it.   Thanks for sharing a part of your Journey with us like that. I feel like I might be missing a lot here, but I donâ€™t really know. I donâ€™t really know much about anything, to be honest. Probably just talking to myself for the most part. Projecting maybe? I donâ€™t know, but I appreciate hearing your perspective. I can only imagine that it adds a positive force to the perceivable world, despite the nature of its coming into being. Which brings up thoughts for me of various themes, from various myths and folklore that Iâ€™ve heard over the years. It loosely brings to mind creation myths for whatever reason.

My husband will go into like a manic phase and have to finish something- but he overdoes it and gets a muscle injury of weakens his immune system and gets sick. My mom would do too much gardening in the hot weather, for example, and make herself sick. And Goggins seems to be this way as well. Its something to watch out for. Maybe those people with strong wills don't have an early alarm system to say- 'watch out, you're reaching your limit- slow down so you have the capacity to push it to the limit another day'. Yes, others may think they are at that point too early, but not paying attention to when you might hurt yourself is not a good strategy for me either. I want to keep my legs- knees hips etc- healthy so I can run as long as possible- because I love running. The way Goggins is- he reminds me of when my daughter was starting to push herself out of me. I was starting to get those contractions and I had to concentrate to work through the pain. I had a nice lady come to talk to me during that time, but she was just distracting me from my concentration to get through the pain. I was walking a fine line, and she was pushing me off it. That is what I feel Goggins is like. He knows it won't take much to push him off his fine line of control. He needs to constantly keep up strong defenses and he can't be distracted from it. He needs to devote a lot of resources to not slipping. So he doesn't have that much to give to other areas. Like considering if being a SEAL and reinforcing the US empire around the world is a worthy use of his effort.

My husband has Tourette's syndrome. His symptoms at there worst were stuttering, making noises, and moving his body in ways that can hurt after a while (like moving his head as if he is getting hair out of his eyes). He also has an iron will- he is Iron Man- and I think it is because he had to learn to try to control his Tourette's to escape ridicule. He had to constantly do something that was difficult for him- control his body. But it gave him an iron will and allowed him to escape his addictions when he decided to (when he began a family and didn't need to escape). I asked him when he started to control himself. The involuntary movements got worse at puberty. He has learning disabilities and only graduated middle school in Taiwan. He had to go out to work at 14. Before the age of 14, he would beat up kids if anyone made fun of him, and fighting felt good to him. But at 14 when he went out to work and his co-workers would ask why he always moved his head weird, he had to control his anger or be out of a job. So from that time he worked on self-control. He has complete control and discipline over his body- his Tourette's manifests more weakly now, but I think that is a function of age. At 60 years old he looks like a gymnast and regularly works out hours a day. Our daughters also have learning disabilities and had to work harder than others. My oldest recently tried to run for 24 hours straight- she had it to 15 hours I believe. She was number one in her high school class but told me others could do  it if they worked as hard as she did. I do think there is something innate in my husband and oldest daughter that is not just born out of facing hardship. I am a teacher and see how a lot of students struggle. Some naturally push more. There is something there that is a gift I believe. Maybe we can all work hard and face hurdles, but some will get to the realization that they need to keep pushing  faster than others. And they will enjoy or habituate to the struggle more than others.

The summary of the video in 10 points  1) Self-Reflection and Internal Dialogue:  Spend time in introspection to understand your own thoughts and emotions. Develop a two-way internal dialogue, acknowledging both positive and negative aspects.  2) Facing Challenges:  Embrace challenges as opportunities for growth and self-improvement. Understand that life is a series of tests, and facing adversity is part of the journey.  3) Taking Ownership:  Take full responsibility for your life and actions. Avoid blaming external factors; focus on what you can control.  4) Embrace Discomfort:  Success often lies outside your comfort zone. Embrace discomfort willingly and view it as a path to personal development.  5) Daily Discipline:  Establish a daily routine that includes self-discipline. Consistency in your actions, even in small things, leads to long-term success.  6) Introspective Cleaning:  Regularly go inward and address the deep-seated issues or fears in your life. Be brutally honest with yourself and confront your inner demons.  7) Resilience and Perseverance:  Understand that failures are part of the journey to success. Learn from failures, and use them as stepping stones toward your goals.  8) Avoiding External Distractions:  Limit external distractions, such as excessive social media and unnecessary commitments. Create focused periods where you can work on your personal growth without interruptions.  9) Overcoming Fear:  Confront and overcome your fears by facing them head-on. Understand that fear is a natural part of growth and achievement.  10) Continuous Learning:  Approach life as a constant learning experience. Be open to gaining insights from various sources and apply them to your personal development.

Andrew I can't thank you enough for this and have to share my immense appreciation and gratitude -- it's changing my life. I'm a new counselor and feel now that it's okay to recognize that radical self love isn't enough... I don't see that being the case for my clients and it's definitely not true for me. I have ADHD and in a big way have been sitting on the question of whether it's worth fighting so hard to achieve what feels like my own version of self actualization. I feel awakened and validated now to channel my own similar strain of inner crazy (HA!) which I disowned a long time ago in the name of self acceptance. It's been so beautiful to reclaim that part of myself and I can't believe now that this ever even felt like a question. It's such a relief to know that a big chunk of my life can just fucking SUCK and that this isn't just a part of my journey but an important requirement that gets me to where I need to be. Thank you again.

Trying to classify gogginâ€™s experience as â€˜stick vs carrotâ€™ oversimplifies it. I think his stick has also become his carrot, or maybe itâ€™s neither a stick nor a carrot but just him going into action every single day, if that makes sense. But I have to believe that itâ€™s not all stick as clearly he feels rewarded (not feeling empty but fulfilled) and is constantly training for that â€˜rewardâ€™ (carrot).  Also Davidâ€™s methodology is unique to some but its philosophy is quite similar to eastern philosophy which focuses a lot on meditation, mindfulness, etc. Thai and Chinese monks would isolate themselves, meditate, and â€˜cleanâ€™ their minds every single day. The difference here of course is that Goggins also goes out into the world and attempts extreme challenges to further push his boundaries and test himself.   The danger of course is that one who goes out into the world would get distracted by outside voices, etc. itâ€™s the reason why monks â€˜leave the world behindâ€™. It is indeed not easy to stay disciplined to oneâ€™s own voice all the time in the outside world. Itâ€™s great that David knows the dangers of social media, and the pursuit of â€˜successâ€™, hence him limiting his exposure and â€˜capping (the outside definition of) successâ€™.

I feel this is the most hardcore I've ever seen David Goggins in a podcast and I've seen every single podcast he's been to. The "Sorry I'm not sorry" attitude and speech, the "I've done all those things to become a strong man so that's why I don't feel sorry for you if you don't" stuff and everything else have probably not been more badass delivered by David, ever. He detests mediocrity and doesn't shy away from telling us straight up that we either grind to become hard like him or we don't, that's it, it's our choice. No hidden agenda or mean intentions, David Goggins is 100% real. If now people don't understand what David Goggins is all about, not even after watching this, then it will probably never happen. He rarely does podcasts these days, he probably felt he said everything there is. I understood David right from the start, I've never been confused about his message, I've never seeing him like probably other people see him (a guy who only works out all day, run and yells at the camera), I knew from the beginning what part that had in everything. Autophagy is a cellular process that involves the degradation and recycling of damaged or dysfunctional cellular components. It plays a crucial role in maintaining cellular homeostasis, preventing the accumulation of damaged organelles and proteins, and promoting overall cellular health. Activating or increasing autophagy through daily cycles or triggers is important for several reasons, which can be explained through two key elements:      Cellular Repair and Maintenance:           Purpose: The primary function of autophagy is to remove and recycle cellular components that are damaged, misfolded, or dysfunctional. By activating autophagy regularly, the cell ensures the timely removal of these problematic components, promoting cellular repair and maintenance.           Significance: This process helps prevent the accumulation of cellular waste, which, if left unchecked, could lead to the development of various diseases, including neurodegenerative disorders and cancer. Regular activation of autophagy is essential for cellular longevity and overall health.      Adaptation to Stress and Nutrient Scarcity:           Purpose: Autophagy serves as a cellular survival mechanism during periods of stress or nutrient scarcity. By breaking down cellular components and recycling their building blocks, the cell can generate energy and essential nutrients to support its functions during challenging conditions.           Significance: This adaptive response allows cells to endure periods of fasting, exercise, or other stressors, promoting resilience and survival. It is particularly important for tissues and organs with high energy demands, such as the brain and muscles.  Experimental and Researched Methods for Activating Autophagy:      Caloric Restriction:           Method: Limiting caloric intake without malnutrition.         Mechanism: Induces autophagy by mimicking nutrient scarcity, prompting cells to break down and recycle cellular components for energy.      Intermittent Fasting:           Method: Alternating periods of eating and fasting.         Mechanism: Triggers autophagy during fasting periods, promoting cellular cleanup and repair.      Physical Exercise:           Method: Regular aerobic and resistance exercise.         Mechanism: Exercise-induced stress activates autophagy, helping to remove damaged cellular components and promoting cellular adaptation.  Possible Autophagocytosis Based on Daily and Intense Physical Activity:      Daily Physical Activity:           Effect: Regular, moderate-intensity exercise stimulates autophagy.         Mechanism: Exercise-induced stress signals the need for cellular cleanup and repair, prompting autophagy to remove damaged components.      Highly Intense Physical Activity:           Effect: Intense workouts can further enhance autophagy.         Mechanism: High-intensity exercise increases cellular stress, promoting a more robust autophagic response to meet the increased demand for cellular repair and energy generation.      Post-Exercise Period:           Effect: Autophagy remains elevated post-exercise.         Mechanism: The post-exercise recovery period is characterized by continued autophagy, allowing cells to complete the cleanup and repair initiated during the workout. Adequate rest and recovery are crucial for optimal autophagy.

Andrew Huberman; David, you embody discipline and doing hard things. Right before we went to hot mics we were talking about learning and right now you are spending some time learning and doing things most people probably donâ€™t associate David Gogginsâ€™ with so why donâ€™t you tell us about it.  David Goggins; Most people just look at me at the guy that runs and yells as heâ€™s running and while I do that to motivate people what people donâ€™t understand is that my day is broken up into segments. I work out, I sleep, I eat but I spend most of my time studying. Iâ€™m in the medical world (paramedic in Canada) but i spend a lot of my time trying to nuke every single about it because Iâ€™m not just trying to be a paramedic and learn about veins, arteries and how the heart pumps and stuff like that. Iâ€™m trying to learn to the point where I can save someoneâ€™s life. Even though paramedics are doing that all over the world, Iâ€™m trying to be that paramedic that can dissect whatâ€™s really going on and figure out what medication goes where and just trying to learn the algorithm as to whatâ€™s going on man and I spend a lot of time doing that.  Andrew; I love the word algorithm because when I teach biology or try to learn anything thatâ€™s related to biology and especially the human body, I need to know the nouns but the verbs are what matter and thatâ€™s really what you are talking about. Because just by saying that brain part there etc. doesnâ€™t tell you how it all works together. So what does your process for studying look like?   David; Iâ€™m not a real smart guy and what I mean by that is, I was born ADD (ADHD) and my brain can not retain information. I am not some genetic freak when it comes to running, learning etc., I am at the bottom of the barrel. So when you ask me this question on what does studying look like for me? I have to go over the same page over and over and over again while Jennifer can look at that page while sheâ€™s quizzing me and learn right there even though she doesnâ€™t know anything about it. Itâ€™s the most frustrating thing how my brain works and so what I do is, I literally sit there with a pen and paper and i go through my books while writing everything down every single day I will repeat the same page until it is photographic memory from writing the same thing down and from there I go and relearn it again. So I learn the bulk of it but then I go and learn the small things within that. So if itâ€™s a medication I first learn how to say the name of the medication, then I go through the dosage etcetera. And this is every single day. Itâ€™s not like â€œoh I got itâ€. Nothing is like â€œI got itâ€. Everything I do in life â€œit sucksâ€. Everything I do in life â€œit sucksâ€. Thatâ€™s when I was 24 years old and 300 pounds there wasnâ€™t some like â€œbig epiphanyâ€ of letâ€™s just go lose some weight and be a navy seal. No! I knew my entire life was gonna be a struggle which is why I just ignored it and I wasnâ€™t even trying to jump off into this shit and learn how to read, how to write,how to memorize and how to become something I am not but through that process something happened to me and I realized, and this is the reason I feel sorry for nobody. In this podcast you are gonna really not like me because people are gonna think, that I am maybe lying or exaggerating. No! I was literally the lowest form on earth, no talent, no ability to learn and I literally know what it is to be rock bottom and build that up. So that question about learning is a pain in my ass and I donâ€™t have to do it and thatâ€™s the thing about it. Iâ€™m 49 years old and a multi millionaire. I donâ€™t have to do anything. All I thought about when I was growing up was â€œman I canâ€™t wait to get to the point where I no loinger have to do this stuffâ€ but as I got older it became a way of living. So how I do every day is how I do every day. Itâ€™s the discipline, the regimen and it was a choice I made. The choice I made was, what am I willing to sacrifice and what am I willing to give up to find every bit of who you are as a human being and I was willing to give up everything to do that. So studying is no joke.

David Goggins. The king of modern go-hard dig-it-out mentality preaching. Alas, for those of us on the Type B spectrum, Goggins is right. If you want to stretch way beyond your ordinary selfâ€”and achieve things you can truly be satisfied withâ€”you just have to grind forward. Despite your emotional state. Despite whether you're "in the zone" or not. Force yourself to do the thing(s). Hate them in the moment, but do the action(s). I'm the laziest guy I know. Laziness is my middle name. But anything I've ever done in my life that I now point to with pride, is because I ignored how much I hated the thing(s) in the moment, and I made myself do the thing(s). And this is all it is. Willpower and motivation, as understood from the many huderman videos:  Set rules, the longer you remain within their bounds, the farther the walls expand elsewhere.  Think of your mind like a fluid, as we know fluids cannot be compressed without exerting force outwards towards the path of least resistance  The path of least resistance when there are no rules is the path that fits the following criteria: 1. The most obvious results 2. The quickest results  3. The most intense results/experience 4. The most novel experiences 5. The most personally relevant/important experience/results  When looking at the rule free life we find that we become lazy.  Laziness is defined as "unwilling to work or use energy"  In our current day life, work is highly valued, so work is important. (Because what is valued by others oftentimes improves self-esteem when achieving it)  You would think that if work is so important that everyone would go do it when taking the perspective that we will do what is important to us. The issue with this is, importance is only 1 part of the path of least resistance.   Other things such as social media, video games, drugs, are actually on the path of least resistance. Those types of things are often labelled as addictions, but really, anything is an addiction. Those things are labelled as addictions only because they do not fit into the value systems of others.   Really, what we call addiction is actually taking the path of least resistance. This makes sense though, people value work, and work is effort. No resistance takes no effort, of course the general population would look down on it.  In the past, the amount of resistance was relatively higher compared to today. Despite that, we find people are not super hard workers all around, which begs the question: is it the average resistance, or the min/max of resistance which is responsible for being able to work?  The answer to that question lies in a few areas, the first of which is in memory. Memories are encoded based on their (3,4) salience and novelty. So, we find that two low resistance factors lead to memory encoding. This is the survivorship bias at play here, what is not fitting of those low resistance factors are not making it home to our memory. Only the low resistance things are making it home, so they are what we remember and gauge our understanding of work/resistance on. In conclusion, the path of least resistance is the path most remembered.   Along with that, the most grueling task we have ever done is used to gauge our understanding of resistance. The hardest task on it's own fits the opposite of the following criteria: (2 and 3) as well as (1) which I will touch on later. The hardest task is usually long and it is something that lies at the extremes for experience in terms of struggle. One more important thing for memory is duration, the longer we are exposed to information, the more possible encodings can take place. Meaning, we remember our most grueling task well, and it informs our understanding of resistance as the maximum. The opposite of criteria (1) is the least obvious result, usually when results are not obvious, we need to add relevance to the task to go through with it. This self-induced relevance is often intrinsic motivation, the longest and most powerful form of motivation.  We now know, our understanding of resistance largely depends on our most and least resistant experience. So, to bring our understanding of resistance up, we have to either, remove low resistance tasks, or add more high resistance tasks.  This is where rules come in as a tool for reducing low resistance tasks. To set an effective rule, you must find things which fit the criteria for the path of least resistance, and forbid yourself from them (whether that is in frequency, duration, intensity, or by omission). Overtime, those memories of those low resistance activities will blur and the minimum for resistance increases to the next thing. This is a progressive strategy where you can omit more and more difficult to remove things, so there is no reason to stop. Everyone has already started this journey without thinking about it this way. We know there are certain limitations to what we can do, there are laws and experiences we avoided having/breaking because we know they are bad.   After the rules are set, it is time to find high resistance tasks to increase the maximum for resistance. Look for things that you don't want to do that are high resistance; for example your homework :/. After picking that thing, do it, as long or as intense as you can will yourself to do. It is important to just start it at all. If it is safe and won't damage you, that is all the planning you need, don't think about it, start that high resistance activity. Once you are used to doing the activity you can begin to think more about it and maximize your gains from it.  In conclusion, to work hard and avoid laziness, you need to adjust your max/min for resistance. Make the lowest resistance task higher resistance than others, and make the highest resistance task something you never thought you can do. Best of luck on your journey down the path of most resistance; make sure to not hurt others in the process. You matter, and are not the only one unable to motivate yourself.

In the grand, unending conversation of science, there's this idea that's more like a secret whisper, really. Imagine, if you will, tearing a little hole right through space and time. It's the stuff of daydreams and deep, starlit discussions â€“ this thought that we could just step through time like walking through a door, that reality could bend and twist, leading us down paths we've only seen in the intricate, spiraling universes of wormholes.  But let's be honest, it's mostly a bedtime story for physicists, isn't it? A beautiful, unreachable "what if" that lives in equations and science fiction novels.  Now, enter David Goggins. Imagine him stepping onto this stage of cosmic theories and starry-eyed hypotheses. He's not just a guy, you see; he's like a walking, talking challenge to the universe. He's where our neat, tidy laws of physics start getting sweaty palms and second thoughts.  Think of Goggins as this extraordinary anomaly, a man who doesn't just push the boundaries â€“ he kind of laughs and leaps over them. It's as if he's got this secret map to places in time and space where the rules aren't the rules anymore. You know, like he's found a backdoor in the grand cosmic design.  It's almost as if he's out there, in the wilds of human potential, having a casual stroll through these theoretical minefields, making physicists scribble frantic notes and rethink their life choices.  This whole thing â€“ it's more than just a chat about what's possible. It's like a campfire story where science and the raw, unbridled spirit of humanity sit down, share a drink, and talk about the universe. It's Goggins, with his feet planted firmly on the ground and his will reaching out into the realms of the impossible, showing us all a glimpse of what happens when you dare to ask, "What if I just... go for it?"  And that's the beauty of it â€“ it's a story that's as much about the stars and the mysteries of space as it is about the heart and the unexplored depths of the human spirit.

This reminded me of a girl who had down's syndrome, and scored the best math exam result when I was a teenager attending school. The math teacher was furious because this girl had exposed all of us. But she outshined us all, and made clear that we were just not disciplined enough.

Today I discovered something, tell me if I am right- Instant motivation is a myth, unless it is related to a serious pain like death of a close one or a break up and so on,  But except for that all this charge up motivation does is give you temporary artificial confidence, that never lasts longer than a few days or months, but what lasts long is the guilt that comes after it, instant motivation makes you believe that you are not that guy who is just lying around doing nothing, but you are this guy who is fully motivated all the time, and the moment the motivation starts fading, you start feeling insecure  Unlike that, I propose another meathod, the 1 % rule - start getting 1% better everyday, now you might ask how do I measure the 1% , it is the amount you can change without letting the brain know that it's pleasure is being parted with, and after some days start challenging the brain little more, and like that but don't just to 50% or 100% , cuz that's just instant motivation which will not develop discipline in you but give you temporary sense of success without achieving anything

What is he doing all this for if he is not even happy doing it or if happiness is not the goal? He should then be aiming  for something higher than happiness like self knowledge or self actualisation or something. Otherwise it sounds like the pain is just an end in itself.  Also he seems to be saying, "just do the opposite of whatever makes you happy". This would mean that a teetotaller who hates alcohol should start drinking heavily because that "sucks" and is painful to do for him.   So there is fundamentally something missing here and I think it is the fact that he is not clear about the goal or the reason why he is doing it. At best he seems to be saying it was a reaction to how much he hated himself or the way he was, but at some point it needs to go beyond that. It has to become an obsession to find some kind of meaning to one's existence, to find some kind of ultimate truth or some ultimate freedom.

I have listened to this conversation three times in the last week.   I wanted to add something that I  live that aligns with David's mental state.   I am a mom to four kids (all one year apart from each other).  My only daughter was diagnosed with chronic illness at the age of one year; she is now 24 years old. I describe her care not as 23 year journey of interventions/care/decisions/emergencies, etc., in  reality the experience of being her caregiver is one long day.... all of that time fighting against the immense want to  escape. Like David said, there is not one minute that I will not do it! I will never 'want' to do it.  My want to escape is based in wishing she did not have to live her life under such intense circumstances. I love her and will always care for her,  all the while feeling the 'friction' and 'haunting'.   Thank you for giving my thoughts validation.

@jameswayton2340 it's the words he uses about mental and physical pain. The absolute distress on the body and the mental anguish of realising that having carried a child inside and then gone through birth, that wasn't the start. It's then a HUGE project. A HUGE job of bringing up a child or children that are constant work for years and mother's carry that. It's like he says... I can't explain it. Then the continual small things, the monotony, the why did I do this? Why am I doing this? Who am I? Where am I? All the jeffin time. Always there. Not like some dad who switches off when he goes fishing or golfing. The only thing Goggins says that's not like a true mother is when he says about providing an needing time to do what he has to do. A mother doesn't do that because she carried the child or children. The only time I know of a mother doing that is the one that got killed going up a mountain. That's how God treats women who live their kids to go off and do what they want. For men, it's different but the hardwork and pain he talks about that he says he can't explain. That's a mother that does that shit. Dads  haven't  physically carried the child so it's going to always be different.

Dr Huberman, thank you for this radically insightful episode. Im 59 and have achieved some modest levels of success as an engineer, culinary graduate, husband and father of four amazing adult children. However, I have plateaued. As a follower of Christ, I am aware of my own wretchedness, my filthy cabinets. My physical fitness and my growth as a chef and husband have stagnated. Dear 300 lb friend, People don't always get it, I understand. Things I wish a friend told me: 1. It can be hard to do basic things when you have a raging auto-immune thing and inflamation. Hire home health care workers to come to your house to clean, cook and shop for things to keep you happy and healthy. Have Huberman pay for it (smirk) or get it free from IHSS. 2. Bleach bath twice a week to cut the itch and the smell. Regular bleach only. Research how to dilute it in the water. 3. Indulge in a simple paper notebook and pens you love. Create a dopamine checklist of all the things you want to do to feel happy and healthy today (e.g Brush teeth, floss, nap, drink water, stare at the sky, walk around a book store, eat, etc). Check it off when you complete something. Don't worry about getting everything done. Recreate the list the next day. 4. Find a therapist to discuss why it feels safe not to fight. What in your past made it seem like it was safer to hide, be invisible. Write about it in your journal. You can get a therapist online in minutes.  5. Write in your journal a list of all the food you want to eat and liquids. The game is to eliminate processed foods and refined sugar. Enjoy what you eat. 6. Cut out one or all activities that feed dopamine addiction. Get obsesssed with your happy healthy checklist instead. Keep finding fun things to do that don't involve a screen (no gaming, p_rn, streaming video, or social media.) Limit screen time to 1 hour a day for healthy things only. 7. Seek doctors advice on medicine. Bimzelx (bimekizumab) was just FDA approved in October 2023. It's a wonder drug for psoraisis. Semaglutide can reduce food noise beause obesity is a disease. Belly and thigh are better than arm injection sites. Enjoy a dental cleaning to reduce brain fog and keep record of your own daily maintenance in your journal.  Try this for 7 days and continue if you feel amazing.  I love you friend. You can feel better.

I will never, ever get tired of listening to Goggins teach. I don't listen to him for discipline or for motivation. I listen to him for one quality - growth. What direction can I take? I've found my internal resources for my discipline. I don't even believe in motivation. I cringe at that word. I found what builds my confidence - doing shit that I don't like! Self-discipline is EVERYTHING! It sucks...yes, it. fucking. SUCKS! I'm 36, starting my career this year and it took me awhile through therapy to accept that I just started my marathon late BUT I started. I fucked off in my 20s and in my early 30s, I was complacent without a pinch of discipline. I relate to Goggins because what pushes him is what pushes me - all of the rejection from women, all of the internal doubt, my low self-esteem, my weaknesses, and what I failed at - I'm coming!  Listen, the science behind what Dr. Huberman discusses is amazing and it feels EXTREMELY good. I LI-TER-ALLY smile at uncomfortable shit because that is growth for me! I win or I learn. I don't lose. I run 4 times a week after work, at night, alone, in the cold, by myself. When people (including my own family) say "it's dark" or "its cold" or "be careful", I can't explain it but something in me brain clicks on. I smile, get my running shit, drive to my running destination, stretch, and run. I don't do excuses. I do NOT like to do any workout, period. It's a feeling. That's it - a feeling of I don't want to. I do it anyway because it's growth. I have learned to only do "me" vs me. I truly, truly don't give a fuck about society. It's a transformation. As you become more focused and digging into that dark place in your mind, you don't want to do shit with anyone. You become a bit off but being off IS you! It's truth because i ALWAYS, ALWAYS find me in the suck. ALWAYS!!!! Now I need to grow more by doing more shit I don't like which is calisthenics.   In the end, I want to be great and I'm nowhere near close to greatness. I don't want to be 70 years old knowing I didn't tap into my potential. Fuck. That! Just do it. Turn that comfortable voice off and GET AFTER IT! Once you learn that you found internal discipline and it's "you", you really do become unstoppable.

My thoughts: I have felt there were three voices in my head for a long time. Our bodies are to be conquered by our mind and spirit; and then our mind by our spirit. A weak mind will deprive the spirit and body and submitting to the body will impede your progress in all aspects of life. Not meaning you may not be â€œsuccessfulâ€ but your success will not be complete.  I have tried to walk the middle ground for a couple decades now and Iâ€™ve not become what I could be (hell).   I will now be extreme in my efforts for my physical, mental, and spiritual development.

Iâ€™m only 20min in and Goggins is speaking big facts about ADHD. I had an opposite scenario where from age 8, I was diagnosed with ADHD, found to have a high IQ, and placed in accelerated courses. Circumstantially, my parents got a divorce and then Iâ€™m living between homes. Not very ideal for focus. Mom got stage 3 breast cancer. Yeah no bueno.   So once middle school hit (12-14yrs old), my grades were slowly but surely falling and I was taking increasingly higher does of medication (soon 60mg vyvanse). Right before highschool I chose to kick it myself because it severely messed with my mood and appetite. What was once a very happy, motivated, social and hungry, child turned into an underweight teen, in not ideal family situation, battling with the regular challenges of American public high school.   My grades plummeted by sophomore year of highschool. I hit rock bottom. I was getting on average 2-4hrs of sleep, unclean room, bad hygiene. Had a meeting with my highschool counselor, the dean, and both my divorced parents who never stood in the same room unless it was court/ for the kids. That meeting changed my life. I decided from that moment on to make life incredibly difficult for myself.  I never continued my medication regularly. After graduating highschool, I got into a 5th choice university, and took out hefty private loans. Not to mention, my parents each co-signed every other loan. If for whatever reason I didnâ€™t make money out of university, Iâ€™m taking my parents down with me. I vowed to never take the ADHD meds unless I can get straight As or damn near em. First semester I was killing it: 4As and a B, I was sleeping at least 6-7hrs, making it to all my classes, excellent hygiene. Since then, I began taking medicine â€˜as needed,â€™ but I still prefer to live my life without it.  As Goggins said, we [those with intense cases of ADHD] have to teach ourselves to focus. I never wanted to be reliant on the medication again. And I wonâ€™t. I have the tools now because I fought through the turmoil of living without them. I set my goals, took failure head on, and rose above.  Fast-forward to junior year of university, I transferred to a better university (one that I was rejected to previously), got scholarships for my grades I never wouldâ€™ve received in highschool, and kept medication usage to only when studying for big exams. To be honest, I didnâ€™t want to go to university at a point. I loved learning, but I hated learning what people thought was best for a boring run-of-the-mill career. But I enrolled and gave it 110%, just to be good at something I despised for the 8yrs preceding it. And I did succeed. Last 3 semesters before graduating I finished with straight As. To succeed at something you donâ€™t like is a powerful skill. The uncomfortable. The doing, for the sake of doing.  Now Iâ€™m living in Israel with my family (please donâ€™t get political in the comments) and before that I lived in Spain. Iâ€™m living my dream. All the money I make, I save or use to pay off my thousands of dollars in loans. The pain and the failures were the best things to ever happen to me. And I still face these struggles. I still face my rock bottom self. Just like Goggins and Huberman discuss it, these things haunt you. Excited for the beast I will become as this is just the beginning.  TLDR F*^% adhd meds, theyâ€™re giving crack to little kids mane. 60mg vyvanse at 12 years old wtf was my psychiatrist thinking. I seriously believe I wouldâ€™ve been 3in taller if I wasnâ€™t MALNOURISHED from a LACK OF APETITE.  Anyway. Thanks for reading my life story. (Iâ€™m 24 now) Good luck my fellow ADHD-havers. Iâ€™m good, but not great. The best catalyst for success comes from within. Find the things you want in life and push with all you got to make it happen. You are capable of so much and the only one who sets those limits are yourself.  Now someone please tell meâ€¦ WHOS GOING TO CARRY THE BOAT?!!?!

Es curioso como Goggins coloca este caso imaginario donde nos tenemos que imaginar como una persona en cuidados paliativos recordando nuestras vidas, haciendo un pequeÃ±o repaso sobre todo lo que hicimos, es obvio que nos vamos a encontrar con grandes fracciones de tiempo perdido dentro de una institucion academica o dentro de un cubiculo oficinista, pero lo que se hace fuera de ello, es lo que realmente le da valor a tu vida, el como enfrentaste el dia a dia, las decisiones que tomaste y los momentos que en dificultad, disfrutaste, porque sabes que dentro de las masivas cantidades de mierda que comistas a traves de tu vida, encontraste algo de valor en ello y lo pusisite a prueba.  Algo que tambien me parecio increiblemente curisoso sobre la entrevista es acerca como Goggins examina la industria de la motivacion, que al parecer es increiblemente rentable. El dice como estos voceros son en su mayoria blasfemos, no existe una cura para la falta de voluntad ni para la falta de motivacion, por eso existe gente que aun paga miles de dolares, euros o pesos en cursos motivacionales para ver si al final pueden levantar su culo y empezar a hacer cosas que realmente represente un premio. Pero la autoayuda o la motivacion no se consigue de en otro lado, SE CONSIGUE DENTRO DE UNO MISMO, HACIENDOLO.  Goggins tiene esta forma de pensar en la que se fuerza a hacer las cosas el solo, en el que se visualiza como uno de los hijos de puta mas cabrones y recibe la motivacion de hacerlas al tener en cuenta todo el proceso por el que ha pasado. Es un proceso de auto reflejo, en el que ve las cosas malas de el mismo y se las explica a la gente sin aminalar la respuesta para que suene un poco mas agradable, LA CRUDA Y ETERNA VERDAD, sin filtros. Goggins es un cabron fuerte y quiero construir la mentalidad que el tiene para hacer las cosas.  EL CEREBRO ES LA HERRAMIENTA MAS PODEROSA DEL MUNDO.  No se puede ser un teorico, necesitas ser un maldito practicante.  Huberman trata de explicar desde sus conocimientos de psicologia (los cuales son pocos ya que el hombre es neurocientifico) y le narra a Goggins como en su cabeza tiene tres voces internas, una que le hace ver la realidad de las cosas, lo que realmente sucede, lo cual para muchos puede llegar a ser terriblemente abrumador, pero tambien hay una voz que recoge eso, lo analiza y lo asimila para que despues haya una contra respuesta hacia esa auto critica infligida por una de las voces internas. Es por eso que nos podemos enseÃ±ar a mirar mas hacia adentro, a encontrarnos con nuestro yo mas fragil, enfrentarlo, sacudirlo hasta los cimientos para despues reconstruirlo. Pero recuerda que es un proceso largo, que como diria Goggins "te demorarias una vida en entender" pero que puedes empezar hacer en cada momento.  EnseÃ±ate a perder, fallar es un arte en el cual se crea la maestria hacia la victoria.  Para finalizar con este podcast, Goggins termina con un discurso que me mantuvo embelesado, en el cual nos invita a pelear con nuestros "demonios" internos, enfrentarlos y encontrar una solucion apropiada a lo que sea que ocurre en nuestra cabeza para asi sacar resoluciones de ello, experiencias que es lo que al final se basa nuestra existencia en este plano material, experiencias, en su mayoria dificiles pero que al fin y al cabo, contribuyen en nosotros. STAY HARD.

Dear Professor Huberman, first things first: your podcast is amazing, I have learned a ton and it has become my go-to format for listening.  There is one thing, though that I am often missing, and that is effect size. For me personally (and I hope for many people out there as well) knowing how much something influences something would be a very valuable piece of information for many of the topics you touch.  One (out of many possible) example: I talked to my 20-year-old little brother recently. He is very much into working out, but also partying and all-nighters at college. Wanting to shine with my newly acquired knowledge I told him about some of the mechanisms and empirical findings you shared with all of us on the importance of good sleep on all kinds of physical and mental functions. I was stopped dead in my track when he simply asked: yeah, but HOW MUCH does it really matter? How much less quality sleep can I get away with (for my gains :)) if I want to keep partying? I couldn't really answer.  I realize that conveying effect sizes (and also statistical significance for that matter) can be difficult. Not least because these things are complicated to grasp, even for experts (coming from a quantitative field myself i know how much I sometimes stumble over at first innocent-looking concepts in statistics). Also, effect sizes might not get reported by all publications. Also, knowing an average of effect might not be enough information when wanting to apply some piece of empirical finding as a tool for myself because I don't know how flat the underlying distribution is. Also, assuming that all causes are (linearly) independent from one another when contributing to a certain outcome might not capture compounding effects.  All that being said, I feel there is immense value in knowing how strong an effect is.  Again, thank you so much for your work, educating all of us about science!  Peter

While I may not know your brother on a level that you might be familiar with, it sounds like a lame, ill-conceived response to a rather serious point that you were trying to make.  Data points to the emphasis you should put on sleep conducive to muscle growth, as well as how much sleep contributes to how well you recover. This is no revelation, look at bodybuilders at the highest level.  You can have a fantastic physique without sleeping normally, of course, but it will always be far less than optimal  It all boils down to preference. If he wishes to never hit his genetic potential/limit in physicality, you canâ€™t stop him.  - someone whoâ€™s trained HARD for some years now

Hey, thanks for answering! I agree with you on the specific point (i.e. I'd still strongly suggest proper sleep to my brother and I am sure he'll come around ;-)). But I still think my general remark is valid (or so it seems to me....). Namely, that understanding effect size ("how much" something is influenced by something) is an important piece of information when trying to properly understand empirical findings.  More elaboration:  I just listened to one of the very first Huberman Lab podcasts again (one about sleep and light for learning) and had 2 thoughts.  1) Professor Huberman himself said in that episode that he wants to cover BOTH, the science and the tools because the tools alone, without understanding the science do not enable you to adjust and filter and be flexible based on your life/circumstances/abilities. Exactly this point: essentially picking and choosing and adjusting the tools he talks about is necessary for (I think) most of us and would be made much easier (again, for me) if I knew more about effect sizes.   2) More specifically: in the mentioned episode he talks about the importance of bright light in the morning and less bright light in the afternoon/evening. This made me think about screen time for my two young kids. They both have their allowed amount of watching TV per day. This happens to usually take place in the evening, due to a variety of reasons (mornings are usually hectic and have to be more efficient; my 6-year-old would get up even earlier if he knew he got to watch TV first thing, etc....). BUT: maybe it would still make sense to not have them sit in front of the TV in the evening because this could improve their sleep (among other things). But in order to decide that I would have to know how strong the influence really is. In the absence of that knowledge, I know about myself that I will just leave it undecided which comes down to not changing the status quo (maybe just my personal mental bias...)  All this points me to the desire to have some quantitative information about effect sizes (to the extent that this is possible, again, I know this can be complicated).   Would like to hear your thoughts on this.  best  PeterÂ @surething3862Â

Round 3 25.02.24 This year has been way better than my previous ones in every single aspect because I've started to face uncomfortable situations FASTER instead of putting them off. There's few feelings that come close to having done something that I didn't want to do. I've just pushed through a critical exam phase with this mindset and reinforced the principles. That being said, after I accomplished the mission, I fell in a slump and overstimulated myself. I felt terrible about my behavior, yet didn't have the "energy" to stop stupid behavior. I was losing the internal dialogue to the weak version of myself. While I've never skipped a day in the atomic habits that I've set for myself (my minimal standard), I've been acting far from my best. The good thing is, that now I've finally learned how shitty it feels to be overstimulated. It feels lethargic, unmotivated, weak, annoying, frustrating and in general just negative. I don't like this feeling and therefore I will adjust my actions to avoid this. Rewatching this episode helps me strengthen my understanding about the dangers of comfort. About the value that discomfort can add to my character.

But there are times in life every one struggles with willpower - I went back to school at 45 and got a job in Tech at the same time. It is so hard, but what is harder is to get fit again. I was in the US Army and very fit, but now after Covid I gained weight and everything hurts - I even built a gym room in my house and still nothing.... so willpower is not the same for everyone and even for the same person it can be difficult to have it equally. Sometimes there is not enough energy to have the willpower in every single part of the life...

Very self confronting. A true human being. We leave a lot on the table. True potential is absolute commitment. The lion and the antelope and nature is 'always on', just like Goggins. There is no off day or gratification. The off day, in nature, is when you get eaten. Humans once lived 'always on' that's how we managed to perpetuate. Externalising our survival and justification through social constructs to protect us from the ravages and impartiality of nature, we have drifted from our true potential. It is almost impossible to be 'always on' in modern society. Yet it can still be done. Still, all paths are not the same. Not everyone needs to be a navy seal or ultramarathoner to become their ultimate self. Leonardo Da Vinci, Mozart, Mother Teresa, Picasso, Charles Bukowski, Octavia Butler, Alan Watts, Mohamed Ali, et al., obsessively followd their deepest passions, to achieve their fulfillment. It is difficult to compare 'greatness' across time and individuals. Every human is more unique than we can possibly imagine. Every life can be inspirational, when we focus individually on 'self realisation' and practice collaborative competition instead of dominant ego serving competition. That's what I love about David Goggins, he only wants to conquer himself and be the best he can be for his souls sake, not to dominate others, but to collaborate through his example with us, as to how we can all reach for what yearns to express in us, through our own unique journey. Amen Goggins. Thanks Andrew Huberman, this is a rocking episode.

Yeah, I learned a long time ago that I was just looking for something to make it easier.  And that's why "it" was always my weakness and I stopped looking.  Still a bit weak, but the point is I stopped pretending that there was a trick to it.  The entire point is to suffer through it, and 100%, most of the time, I simply am not willing to pay the cost.  But I refuse to gaslight myself that I can haggle down the price anymore and that has benefit me greatly.  The only thing that actually helped was perspective.  Realizing that envy is not really a motivator.  It's easy to want someone else's results because you have no notion of your life after paying the cost so it seems like they got it for free, even if you watch some cute montage of how hard they supposedly worked.  It doesn't sink in and seems like "it must be nice."   A lot of our motivations are recognition, which I think for most people are really vanity.  Real things like health, addiction, relationships, productivity are not usually as glamourous as the things we think we want to achieve because someone else got a lot of credit for them.  Realizing the things that actually matter to me did make it, I won't say easier, but made it necessary to walk over the spikes to get them.  That I think is the most important assessment that is probably easy for most people not to make because of too many comparisons with others.

I always like listening to Goggins interviews because his mindset is so unlike the status quo.  I was pumped to know that Dr. Huberman was having him on.  On one hand, I hope that he's able to get to a place where, even as he uses the negative events of his past as fuel, he is able to identify less with that past and more so with who he has become.  ON THE OTHER HAND, I love his 'no excuses', 'no nonsense' mindset.  He helps us all to see that we really don't have excuses either, and that we need to start being honest with ourselves so that we can extract the greatness that resides inside of all of us.  The way that he lives his life almost makes him like a sort of guinea pig for us to see what humans are capable of.  We're so comfortable in our society!  The thought about exploring oneself so deeply is indeed frightening.  As a personal trainer, I can't imagine doing some of the physical feats that he's done - and continues to do - but I am pushed to expand my thinking.

Long post about some change that occurred in my life, if you donâ€™t feel like reading you can skip.   David describes my life as someone with ADHD. I was always like this, suffering from insecurity, I gradually started fixing my mentality, what helped was seeing my progress and seeing how I got better than the people around me. I think the last straw was when 2 relatives from the medical profession told me while we were discussing stuff: â€œYouâ€™re actually goodâ€. That was it, that was the final moment of my insecurities, all of the hard work on improving myself, positive visualization, doing work, eliminating distractions (I was using the methods Huberman advices before I even know he existed)â€¦ I got self sustained, then that affirmation from 2 veterans in the field, it snapped.  Now Iâ€™ve got a mentality similar to Goggins and Tate (controversial, donâ€™t agree with many stuff he says, but the mental aspect of him I like it). Iâ€™m of course not on their level of mental toughness, but Iâ€™m way better than 4 years ago, and 4 years ago I was way better than 8 years ago. Progress is all that matters, I am my own competitor, as long as Iâ€™m overcoming myself, Iâ€™m satisfied.   1 semester away from being a doctor In my 2nd year when the p1andemic hit, I got the toughest period in my life, everybody told me to quit, everybody blamed me why I canâ€™t pass while others can, everybody told me to compromise and take an easier route. I was alone, no one in my family stood but against me even though I know they love me and want the best for me but thatâ€™s parenting for you. It was very cold and looked timeless, it was like a prison without bars, where were all of the so called friends? They disappeared. It was only me in there against everything and everyone. I went from hating my life back then, to going on a roll, not only in university, but I started eating healthy, cooking, then I learnt a martial art, now Iâ€™ve got a lean physique.   I look back now with a smile, I donâ€™t hate my life, I actually love that kid in the past, I understand him, and I appreciate how stubborn he was to rise up from the ashes like a phoenix.  I completely understand and empathize with David. I never knew this was his story. My respect to him is through the roof right now.   Hope everybody else makes it, if you work for it, you earn it, against all odds.

Like most one size fits all advice. This will work for some people, and is totally idiotic for others. And i disagree. Im a great guitarist. The road to becoming an expert in my field was not "hell". It wasnt always a grind and miserable. The vast majority of that time was a great joy. And i dont know if David is just a less optimistic person, or if this negative grind of his is a conscious play as to be part of his brand and appeal.   And its the same with getting in shape. Im no olympic lifter, but i went from beer drinking beer belly, to pretty excellent lean muscle mass. Again, there was some sacrific and hard work, but the process was mainly playful, explorative and joyful.  Not knocking him. His message has clearly helped thousands of people. Just saying it wont reaonate and work for others, partly because of differing paychologies, but also partly because his premise just isnt true.

Hey Andrew!  First of all, thank you so much for the work you do with these podcasts. I enjoy them so much, and I enjoy a lot the variety of topics, the sense of details you put in it and they way it is very easy to understand and to get the points, even for my as a guy from Austria and not native-speaker of Englishâ€¦   I am a musician and therapist and dedicate my life in observing, discovering, unveiling and diving into myself.   This means in an emotional way: getting to know my emotions, give them their place and space and time, crumbling down walls, release old trauma, learning to love the parts of myself that are very resisting to change etc.   This means in a spiritual way: getting to know my heart space, learning to forgive myself and others, expand my heart space to hold a lot of things this life just brings by living it (with in my case having four children haha), offering spaces for people to come together for praying, singing, exploring inside and connection to something bigger than this human life. Etc...  This means in physical way to have a routine that strengthens my body and focus, healthy eating etc etc, all the well known thingsâ€¦  So, in many of these things your podcasts helped me, sometimes a lot, sometimes in a little details, all together in a great way. Thanks for that!  It feels important to me to reach out to you and tell that there is one thing, I am really missing in that:   It is to point out, that all this â€self-optimizingâ€œ practices include the danger of being very hard to yourself, of not learning to also be gentle, self-caring, self-loving with yourself. I am writing this after hearing this episode I comment, as it again points out to me, that this is in many things I hear from you, a missing hint. To me, all things things you talk about (or let other people talk about with you) make a lot less sense, if you not also focus on a healthy relationship to yourself in a soft way, not too much disciplined way, not self-(and of course other) judging way of living.   So please, donâ€™t get me wrong, the benefits and good sides I enjoy listening to you and your guests are by far more influential and beneficial. But maybe considering a guest to talk about something off-scientific topic speaking about things I descried up in the text? Would love to heart that too in your style.  Again, thanks for your good work, blessings and greetings from Austria.  Andeo

for me, they key thing has been to exclude a lot of things, to sacrifice a lot of things, for other things. a lot of people dont want to do this understandably and think they have time to do everything (including me) but i think it is very necessary for growth to understand how painfully few hours of time youve got. take news for example. do you really need to know every single thing musk does every day for example?  or keep up to date with all the latest tech news or whatever? unless you are working in that industry no you do not. actually even if youre in that industry you probably dont. even working out. sure its good for the health but a lot of people in my opinion overdo it and they spend too much time in the gym and they do it for vanity reasons more than health. so i cut down my workout time to a few times per week, and i do it at home, i dont even go to the gym.  the second thing is to know yourself. if you go too hard for too long you will hit a brick wall and burn out. or destroy your knees, like he did with his running. is that really a good idea? so you have to work hard yes but work smart too. i dont believe the "only stick" approach works for everyone, and i actually dont believe that he is quite telling the truth about it either. he says things still suck but hes a multi millionaire and hes got a girlfriend or wife. thats not stick, thats carrot. if everything was all stick from cradle to grave why not just end it right here and now?   also and this is super important: DONT COMPARE YOURSELF TO OTHERS. we all have different difficulties different backgrounds different traumas different skills. some of the things i have overcome probably look idiotically simple to others. like opening certain software and beginning to learn it, or cleaning my apartment. but for me these were MASSIVE obstacles to overcome. think about that before you judge others too. for me going to the gym is like a reward, its the easiest thing in the world its like an escape from everything. but for others its almost impossible to doand they hate it.

David Goggins is one great example of hard work, discipline, finding one's purpose and constant effort of pursuing that very purpose. Still, life itself is a subjective experience. Things happen, but we filter them through our own internal emotional cocktail. That being said, there is no universal recipe for success, as there is no universal definition of success. It's different for each and every one of us. We have to put in the effort to live a life we are proud of, that makes our hearts full of joy and gratitude for today and excitement for tomorrow.

This episode helps to resolve eternal questions of philosophy and pure science. 1. Freedom of will. Can human do what he wants? Philosophers grind it for centuries. Frankly, that's simple. Of course he can, only within reasonable limits. Just set accessible goals. This sort of willpower faces mainly external obstacles. 2. This is more complicated. "I don't want, but will do it." How is it ever possible? I mean, everybody knows this from own experience, but how to arrange it on the level of neural circuits? The classical scheme is motivation -> action. You have a motor image in prefrontal cortex + desire, emotional activation from the limbic system (let it be cingulate gyrus). No desire - the image will disintegrate. No motivation - no action. I guess, a positive emotion still exists, but this is controversial. From cybernetical point, the brain is a multiparametrical regulator. You really pursue several goals simultaneously. Something is attractive, others - repulsive. Willpower is the ability to go on in such environment.

And these are my favorites: ADHD tips from therapists:  - Utilize timers and incorporate breaks into your routine. - Cultivate self-compassion throughout your journey. - Embrace your unique approach to tasks. - Prioritize the importance of taking breaks for overall well-being. - Opt for a menu-style list instead of a traditional to-do list. - Extend time estimates for tasks to accommodate potential challenges. - Utilize written notes for information storage, allowing your brain to focus on processing. - Engage in activities that promote both immediate and future well-being. - Organize your environment to support positive habits. - Break larger tasks into manageable, incremental steps. - Avoid setting unrealistic expectations; instead, focus on realistic outcomes.

Many men slave away to earn money, fame, women, etc i.e. "conquer the world".  Goggins and probably 5% of men have channeled their rage, passion, "demons"...to conquer THEMSELVES.  That is the difference between the 5% and the 95%.  The question is WHAT was his motivation? WHAT flipped the switch for him to choose this path?  He's tried to explain it but it's impossible to explain unless you've experienced it.  I only did once with end stage cancer...refused medical tx of any kind.  Drank 100 ounces of carrot juice (try juicing that much with zero energy, I had to dig deep), did coffee enemas, took 8 grams of curcumin daily, and FORCED my low energy ass to walk the block several times daily.  That's all I did, but it was HARD.  I HAD to dig deep...or die.  (There are cureS, it was simple, but not EASY by any means).  David wasn't forced to, but still managed to, which I find intriguing.  Even now, years after recovery, perfectly healthy, doing low carb mostly carnivore, and some physical accomplishments like a black belt, I STILL have trouble digging deep to get my ass to the gym, exercise more, pursue goals, etc.  But I tap into that switch I experienced to save my life, and I'm usually amazed by what I can do.  Our minds lie to us.
