I wish someone would ask Goggins the hard questions.  Reading his first book he described in detail how his father was ambitious, how he would hob nob with famous people and prided himself as a power player in the greater Buffalo area.  He described how his father abused his mother, his siblings, and himself.  How he was a slave driver at the roller rink.  Goggins' dad was a hard man and meeted out punishment on those around him.    One of the main things Goggins harps on is being a 'great' man as if this is the ultimate ideal to shoot for.  Does he not realize his dad had the same goal?  In order to become great he punishes himself...and has come to enjoy it.  In a way he is taking his father's approach and turning the punishment inward.  According to Goggins, his father was an incredibly selfish, self-serving person.  A lot of Goggins' advice centers around selfishness...and he has three failed marriages to prove it.  He's basically said that the women in his life weren't aligned with his goals (which centered around himself and his own greatness) and he left them.  I'd like to hear more about how he treats his family and the children of his exes.  The fact is the body will eventually break down, we all die, no one gets out alive.  While you can climb the mountain and eat the pain, maybe for life, in the end what is your legacy?  FIghting everyone and everything or selflessly loving those around you?  As hard as Goggins is, you would think he could handle the challenges of a relationship with another human.    This is coming from someone who admires a lot of what he says and stands for.  I am sure thousands of people will be impacted in a positive way particularly in the area of the mental game as it relates to obstacles, challenges, etc.  The point though is that we shouldn't glorify one aspect of the human condition over all others as if that is the be all end all of living a life well, especially if the driver behind it is trauma from someone who used a similar approach to evil ends.

I got a years worth of organising, getting rid of stuff,cleaning and rearranging that was on my to do list since last year done TONIGHT. From 1am-5amâ€¦  Itâ€™s not the regimented, dopamine controlled, flow state that i scour Huberman Lab to obtain.. but this guys and Sheila Buffâ€™s JUST DO IT approach.  Having ADHD is a pain and I carry so much grief of feeling misunderstood and depressed from the part of myself that seeks stimulation and dopamine and reward in order to do a task. The lack of credibility I feel I have from loved ones that simply can not relate.  But time and time again Iâ€™ve proved that I can be a beast when I know what I have to do.  Tomorrow, Shit.. I have plans. I will be exhausted. But thankfully I did something tonight that will benefit my whole year while listening to this. I searched this channel at the right exact time. Hang in there guys and have faith in your self to overcome your obstacles.   I will say as a daughter of someone in the military, I heavily rejected this approach of grinding with tenacity and force. I enjoy the flowers and little playlists I make while pushing the boulder up the hill. Itâ€™s important to incorporate joy and gratefulness into your routines.

Woah is the first thing I could manage to say after listening to this episode of the Huberman podcast. Something struck a deep nerve for me. That feeling you have when you are completely alone with your thoughts and you realize how lost you are, inadequate and not living up to your potential.  I think David Googins perfectly encapsulates this using his body language and his words to describe exactly where the mind goes when you are in a rumination of misery and despair. You can see it in his eyes that heâ€™s been there many times before and I have to say that is more powerful and motivating than learning productivity hacks. These success routines we buy into only glamorize the positive and comfortable emotions which is really a farce in the end because comfort is not going to be the thing that motivates you which is what David Goggins points out. Many successful people sugarcoat and donâ€™t go into the true grit and struggles it takes to be successful. David Googins is here to share the hard truths that nobody wants to hear and think about.  I honestly find it really refreshing to see his genuineness and candor shine through. He is a deep soul and there is no question that his will power is stronger than steel and it didnâ€™t happen overnight. Thank you for this podcast and for the wake up call I needed and many others probably needed too ğŸ™ğŸ»

Respect to him, but i must say I have a different perspective. For me it's about the journey, NOT the goal. Everyone always asks "what is your goal in life?". I think it's the wrong question to ask. A better question is "What journey in life do you want to go on?". The reason I think this is better is because most of your life is a journey, so you better enjoy the journey!   Let's say your goal is to reach top of Mount Everest. Does it REALLY matter if you reach the top? For me, I'm happy to go half way, I still enjoyed the journey. The goal, lasts maybe one day, the journey can be weeks or months.  I'm writing a book at the moment. I'm enjoying the journey. Do I need a goal that the book has to be out in 6 months, or it needs so many readers or be a best seller? No!  If you enjoy the journey, quite often a successful by product will happen naturally, but pressuring yourself to have a painful journey to meet a goal is looking at life from the wrong angle. Have any studies identified what the aMCC looks like in people living with chronic illness? Daily life with a chronic illness is usually filled with micro sucks and serious macro sucks may come up on a regular basis. These sucks are also often directly related to survival/a willingness to live. Iâ€™m sure that there would be differences in these people due to varying levels of challenge, environments, resources etc., but nevertheless, I know that some people persist and thrive through their illness(es), and I imagine that they must end up with rather developed aMCCs.   I know much of the data around this structure is fairly recent, but I was too curious not to ask. (Also I am using language from your video with Chris Williamson because thatâ€™s actually where I first heard you talk about the aMCC.)   I wanted to put the question first because the following may be a bit tldr, but I did really want to say thanks Andrew Huberman. I have felt incredibly grateful for all of the content that you put out, not only for my own sake, but for that of the whole world. This episode may be the most compelling one for me to date, as I canâ€™t seem to help writing to you in the midst of racing thoughts and feelings. You presented me with some very valuable knowledge (the info about the aMCC and the real David Goggins), at a very important time.  In this case, the immense gratitude extends simultaneously to David Goggins, for being who he is, and for being honest about his raw and genuine self. I have never had an expectation that I would find people who think in the ways that I do, nor do I feel a need to find them for me to continue thinking/living in this manner. But I may have had the hope, and certainly canâ€™t deny the power of connection, along with the reassurance, comfort, and inspiration that I felt hearing from someone who thinks in this way and is living the life of the stick.   ğŸ™ğŸ”¥

I must say I have a different perspective. For me it's about the journey, NOT the goal. Everyone always asks "what is your goal in life?". I think it's the wrong question to ask. A better question is "What journey in life do you want to go on?". The reason I think this is better is because most of your life is a journey, so you better enjoy the journey!   Let's say your goal is to reach top of Mount Everest. Does it REALLY matter if you reach the top? For me, I'm happy to go half way, I still enjoyed the journey. The goal, lasts maybe one day, the journey can be weeks or months.  I'm writing a book at the moment. I'm enjoying the journey. Do I need a goal that the book has to be out in 6 months, or it needs so many readers or be a best seller? No!  If you enjoy the journey, quite often a successful by product will happen naturally, but pressuring yourself to have a painful journey to meet a goal is looking at life from the wrong angle. Just my opinion.

Â @wrfootball3847Â  I love the perspective. Iâ€™m wondering how can one switch from seeking a goal to enjoying the journey ? I think society as a whole glorifies the goal 100% I do too. But enjoying the journey sounds more peaceful. But the question is How can I enjoy the journey without the goal ? Or enjoy the journey without a reward ? Itâ€™s not easy to digest because thereâ€™s no goal during the suck ?

Â @wrfootball3847Â  If you set yoyrself a goal and you are happy if you only make it half way but then you are happy with the journey, then don't make the goal because that is just a weak mindset. If you set yourself a goal you need to tell yourself you are gonna achieve it and grit your teeth in the hard moments and eventually achieve the goal u set out to achieve! STAY HARD

I'm a bit confused on the brain part that grows if you're doing something you don't want to, shrinks if you enjoy it...   For people with Major Depression, getting out bed can be the hardest thing, something they really don't want to do. And they do it. So wouldn't this part grow, and then eventually they'd have the will to take care of themselves better? Like they know they should brush their teeth, sleep and eat well, etc. But they just don't have the will to do so.. I do understand that depression isn't quite that simple, but would love some clarification.   And in my personal experience I might really hate doing whatever habit I'm trying to implement (right now, getting up, out of bed, and outside at the same time each day). I do not want to do it. So, this part of the brain is growing. But eventually, as I know from personal experience, I'll begin to enjoy and cherish those moments in the morning... and then that part of the brain will shrink? But, I'll have more desire to instill better habits... I don't know, I think more conversations about these findings would be helpful.

I strongly relate to this guy in so many ways, but I definitely use carrots in combination with the internal approach. I have lots of trauma and didnâ€™t have a shield either. I also have adhd and cognitive disabilities and every day life is very challenging for me. I too push through and have made some big changes. My faith and motivation to overcome the challenges has been the things to keep me going day after day even though itâ€™s hard. I lean into the pain a lot too and am obsessive with many things. Many people donâ€™t believe I have a cognitive disability or anything because of how high I function, but they donâ€™t see how hard things are. One thing I will say is different about me is that I see a lot of value in everyone, including myself, even when I am not overcoming and succeeding. I learned about ableism in school and how harmful it is. I feel like health and success are important, but it is important to see other people as having value regardless of these things. No one is a piece of shit in my view so I donâ€™t like that ideology. If I had to choose to be friends with a kind person who was overweight and low functioning versus a high functioning fit person who is mean then I will for sure pick the kind person. I would like to be a fly on the wall for the every day interactions he has with people. What are those scheduled times of super love and affection like? I guess he is up front about it and the person agrees so it should be good. I appreciate upfront communication for sure because people do love the lie and self awareness is key. Iâ€™m just a bit nervous about the compassion and empathy, but like I said Iâ€™d have to see him interacting with people. Maybe heâ€™s a sweety to his woman and family.

Excellent podcast.   The way David spoke the truth about the real struggle of having ADHD, and how focus and learning is so monumentally difficult, and his iron determination to do the work even if it's unbelievably hard...  gives me hope. I'm 52, and have struggled with ADHD my whole life.  School as a kid and teen was excruciating. Work as an adult is just as excruciating. I went undiagnosed only until recently, and only now I'm finally starting to understand ADHD, and how it impacted my life, mentally and physically.   David speaks the truth to the heart of the matter, doesn't sugar coat, is motivating and inspiring.  When he says that listening to so many people on social media who talk about all the ways you can help yourself doesn't really work... and the work can only come from yourself..I mostly agree.  I've listened to hundreds of self help podcasts, and none "worked" , none really "hit home"...  I've learned a lot from listening, yes, and I enjoy them very much. And am greatfull.    But, I think David is right when he says ya gotta dig into yourself find out if you want to do it,, then do it yourself.  There is no other way. Thank you Mr Huberman for a great podcast.â¤

How does one start doing the hard things? How do you know you actually donâ€™t like doing the hard thing that grows the anterior cingulate cortex? And, perhaps Goggins commitment to doing hard things is what has helped him overcome his ADHD? Possibly other habits and tools as well. All the exercise he does assuredly helps with that. Iâ€™m particularly interested in how he has been so persistent and consistent despite having ADHD and doing things heâ€™s apparently not interested in or doing things he doesnâ€™t want to do. One thing that really intrigues me is the vision he had of himself at some point and knowing the person he wanted to be. When you all talked about the carrot and the stick it seemed to me that thereâ€™s two carrots in some way not a traditional carrot like an external reward but still a positive future gain so Iâ€™m labeling it a carrot though maybe not the right word. That is the person he wanted and continues to want to become and the process itself. But, interestingly the idea of doing things you donâ€™t want to do and embracing the process seem to be a bit at odds with each other. Iâ€™d be curious to see how these mindsets might be teased out in some neurological tests or neuroscientific experiments. Like is the idea of â€œlove the processâ€ learning to enjoy what you donâ€™t like and does that mindset shift affect the growth of the anterior cingulate cortex? According to the findings Huberman mentioned it seems that learning to love the process may be poor advice if we want to keep strengthening and growing.

Agassi went to the desert in Nevada, and Federer used to go to Dubai to train in 100++ degree heat, on purpose, smh. 100% This. Congratulations! I can completely relate to this struggle as a woman with ADHD that wasn't diagnosed until my mid-40s. Held back in 2nd grade, had difficulties with relationships, procrastination, and low self-esteem. Somehow got it in my head to go to college and had to work so much harder than my peers. Reading pages over and over again, making flashcards, elaborate diagrams and never feeling like I had information completely memorized to pass an exam. I managed to make it through nursing school and eventually a masters degree in nursing and family nurse practitioner. It's a daily struggle.

I have ADHD and I do very well in school - because I don't memorize. I understand the "story" behind the information and look at it as a puzzle I'm filling in. That way, it just sticks. With ADHD, if you're not actively interested, shit doesn't stick around. I love learning about the topics I like learning about. That's the only reason why I learn them. Also, teaching things to others is actually the best way to learn, so Jennifer is the one in the best learning situation there, not David
But also, much respect for learning that way

I have a question, I mostly agree with what Goggins said but I still felt like he was too extreme sometimes with the message he's preaching, it gave me the idea that he wants or at least hope for everybody to follow the same path of hardwork he did, and if they don't, they re labeled as weak or missing something. And some parts like when he stopped playing Baseball, which he liked, just for the sake of being hard on himself makes no sense to me. If he wants to live that way I respect him and it's rlly motivating to know oneself can be like that, but in my opinion I really think life should be about equilibrium between discipline and having fun Maybe I didn't get the message or I misinterpreted his message, this is why I'm commenting and I'm looking to hear you guys opinion on it,  because after scrolling trough the comments all I see is people agreeing with it without giving different points of view, it's almost like they re following him just for the sake of it even tough most part ain't doing half of what he is preaching. It's like "he's right, I'm the problem and I have to change" without rlly critically thinking about it and wondering how they can apply it on their life, because I know for sure most of the people that say that ain't gonna do shit and maintain the long term discipline he did. Plus he says everyone is an individual and should be different and not follow a pack, yet almost feels like he feels like he's better than everybody just because they don't follow the same philosophy as he does while using the example of random people asking him "I'm missing something in my life" and generalizing that everybody who don't live a life full of discipline everyday will  miss something in their life, so his way is the only way.  This is not a hate, just genuine question, because that's what I interpreted from the message he passed on this video, it doesn't mean I disagree what he said fully, I'm actually thankful to hear abt what he said and his message helped in a way, I just don't think he's fully right with it, thank you

First As much as I like Goggins and still find his words inspirational I think it is important to note that for people who have injuries such as depression, PTSD, or sever injuries his words are occasionally used by people to be abusive to those who are injured and to not feel empathy towards them or help them.   Second  It would be nice to hear that there are situations where his words are not only not applicable but rather harmful to the ability of someone to succeed or heal.  It would be nice if he would spend more time describing his internal and external rituals he uses to compensate for his disabilities and neurosis.  As someone who has dealt with things such as dyslexia and ADHD and who has had to relearn how to read because of a TBI I am aware that the little things we do as mental and physical rituals make a big difference.  As an example; counting your blessings produces chemicals in the brain that can offset depression or that imagining doing physical exercise even when you aren't physically capable of it produces endorphins that help the body heal like you were exercising.  Third As someone who has suffered acute depression and anxiety due to a traumatic brain injury and faced the demons of prolonged suicidal ideation I feel that his words that show a lack of empathy for those who cannot control their emotional state regardless of their physical condition to be very hurtful and dangerous.  People do not choose to stop eating or to commit suicide from depression they are killed by.  If the water was rising on the ocean and you walked across a man who was buried up to his head in hard sand you should not tell him he is weak for and deserves to die if he cannot do it himself.  This is the same as being physically injured with a TBI or other forms of mental illness.   Thank you Goggins for your efforts to help people with your inspiring life and your honest intent to help.  Please consider mentioning a couple small things so those of us who suffer through these experiences aren't cast aside to die whimpering while I families watch quoting your words for why they don't need to feel bad for not helping and ridiculing us.

Wow.  Conscious mind.  Makes sense.  We are in alpha brainwaves when getting our eeg taken.  Thus, the inattentive ADHDers are the Day dreamers.   I detect weight differences which sparks my memory. An envelope with one less piece of paper is noticed my memory remembers its original weight. Yet, to recall factoids on a subject I despise, like calculations for a formula that I'll never use for a test, is awful.  Thus Using kinetic movement, walking and reading outloud these boring factoids, really helped me to set things into memory.    Military people get the training we all ADDers need to succeed. My father had 2 years in conscripted service, and had all the symptoms of Inattentive too.  Yet, he followed suit, got up, got to work, and did his work with percision because of the training in the military.   I however, can see many of us are different from one another regardless of also having ADHD.  There is a "risk taking" gene that Goggins may have, that I don't, so to speak. I believe intelligence can be increased, by optimizing the missing ingredients in the body itself, example, B6 = more dopamine, Gaba = more persistence due to less anxiety, etc. Not all folks have the same deficits, but testing will help to decide what to try.  I don't think for example, that Saffron which is being pushed as a Ritalin substitute is for everyone, some of us have sensitivity to even Turmeric so following the crowd, is not a good thing.  Lucikly, we get rejected so often that we don't follow the crowd anyways.

25:44 This is the human dilemma. Hardship/trauma can result in exceptionalism which in a perverse sense can justify it, but not all hardship/trauma results in exceptionalism and not all exceptionalism is driven by trauma/hardship. I have heard many times from people who have suffered then triumphed, whether it's overcoming injury or illness, poverty, various forms of psychological/emotional or physical/sexual abuse, etc, have said they either recognize that the trauma created who they are and they wouldn't change, and in certain ways are grateful for it.

I gotta say, as humble as he is about most things, he's not humble about his supposed greatness. Greatness is not self defined, it is externally defined and his accomplishments pertain essentially to himself and himself alone. He is a fantastic physical specimen. He is a fantastic mental specimen. He is not a man of greatness sorry. He has contributed virtually nothing to the grand scheme of society and THAT is what defines greatness. There are plenty of smart scientists for instance, but do you know why only men like Bohr, Einstein, Heisenberg, Hawking, Durac are considered men of greatness in the scientific community? Because they fundamentally altered the structure of science and our collective, species wide understanding of it. In the ancient world, you know why Alexander of Macedonia, Ghangis Khan, Marcus Aurelius, Cleopatra, Nefertiti are considered individuals of greatness? Because their leadership and ideas, fundamentally changed the course of human history. That is what it means to embody greatness. I'm sorry, but Goggins doesn't even come close to true men and women of greatness.

Carl Jung proposed that the only way to become whole & maximize the potential of the psyche was to do the hard inner work in efforts to sublimate, or bring to the surface, the unconscious. Integration of one's unconscious into the Conscious was the way to overcome traumas, complexes, and the hard wiring of our early years. This is where he diverged from and disagreed with Freud. Freud believed we were destined by are formative years, Jung argued that we can overcome all that was embedded early by going into the abyss and bringing to light what has been stored in the darkness. This man is a great and determined human.  I had no idea he was in the tribe.  ADHD.  As an inattentive female no one caught on nor did I...that I had this too.  Until 44. I did receive a massive spanking for being late in grade 4.  Lucky I was not a boy that lady (teacher) would have had her ugly wig for breakfast.  I was not hyper.  But heavily timid. I lied about why I was late ever since.  Thank God for a terrible public transit.    My short-term memory for tests required walking up and down my hall while reading outloud. All highlighted in different colours.   I hope he sees this. He could try that.   It adds the vocal to the study and body movement.  That was in the 70s.  In the 90s I was vindicated.  Some Japanese Doctor started to use brain scans and noted that seniors who read out loud retained more.   No scan in my day.  But I figured it out.   I wanted to go to University.  Archelogy,  Art. English.  I could never make up my mind.  So at 36 went to college and got an associates degree. Corp Comm.  I had to quit Computer Graphics Technical the "professor" wanted to know my IQ.  My then bf had one of 130.  So I told him.  Me guy has an IQ 130.  And I am the one who caught him.  So I may be smarter.  Should have seen the goof's face.  I quit that course.  Everybody else was saying in 96 that I should have started to get into Multimedia.  30 years later.  That heart ache is still looming over my head.

Good evening, gentlemen.  This podcast has provided profound insights into internal conflict, mindfulness, and taking specific action.  I openly admit that I grapple with my internal dialogue, which often feels like it's tearing me apart on a daily basis.  Now armed with knowledge on how to combat these negative voices, creating a resilient persona capable of withstanding life's challenges and facing inner demons head-on without faltering, while also enhancing and fortifying the part of the brain associated with overcoming obstacles, will undoubtedly have a significant impact on my day-to-day life.  I've taken the liberty of copying some of the transcript and started delving into the newfound knowledge it imparts.  I hope to apply it effectively and wisely, recognising that there's a wealth of insights and battles waiting to be discovered in those metaphorical cupboards. As Mr. Goggins said, 'If you don't know how to fail, there is no victory,' and 'So the first part of my success was learning how to fail properly. And then eventually, I started getting a few victories.'  While the challenges may seem daunting, I'll leave the 'Christmas presents' where they belong. (Haha)  Once again, thank you for the honesty and straightforward explanations, Mr. Goggins and Mr. Huberman. May God spare you to continue influencing more lives positively.

ğŸ¯ Key Takeaways for quick navigation:  00:00 ğŸ§  Introduction to David Goggins and his background - David Goggins' impressive achievements, including being a retired Navy SEAL and ultramarathon runner. - Mention of his books and his challenging upbringing, leading to personal transformation. 08:07 ğŸ’ª David Goggins' approach to learning and discipline - David's dedication to learning medicine, specifically paramedicine. - His process of studying, which involves writing and repetition. 15:16 ğŸƒâ€â™‚ï¸ The difference between running and studying for David - How David's focus during running and studying is completely different. - The intense level of concentration and suffering involved in both activities. 19:58 ğŸƒâ€â™‚ï¸ Overcoming Misunderstanding and Misconceptions - David Goggins emphasizes that achieving greatness requires a deep commitment and a willingness to be misunderstood by others. - He highlights the importance of putting every ounce of focus and effort into one's goals. 20:53 ğŸŒ… Friction as a Catalyst for Growth - Goggins discusses how friction in life is essential for personal growth and development. - He mentions that his day starts early in the morning and involves facing challenges right from the beginning. 22:21 ğŸ§  The Barbaric Nature of Greatness - Goggins delves into the idea that true greatness requires an almost obsessive mindset and extreme discipline. - He emphasizes that the path to greatness isn't pretty, and it can be challenging for others to understand. 24:43 ğŸ“– The Limitations of Sharing the Experience - Goggins explains that his journey to greatness is difficult to convey through books or documentaries. - He emphasizes that the process of pushing oneself to the limit and extracting greatness can't be fully understood without experiencing it. 27:35 ğŸšª The Power of Haunting Experiences - Goggins talks about how haunting experiences in his childhood and young adulthood played a crucial role in shaping his character. - He discusses the lack of support and mentorship he received during his early years and the impact it had on him. 30:24 ğŸ­ Striving for Authenticity in a World of Facades - Goggins expresses his frustration with the inauthenticity often displayed on social media. - He shares his desire to reveal the harsh realities of life and the struggles he faced. 35:05 ğŸ¥• The All-Stick, No-Carrot Approach - Goggins discusses how his journey has been primarily driven by discipline and the avoidance of negative consequences. - He highlights the absence of a traditional "carrot" in his life, focusing instead on the relentless pursuit of self-improvement. 40:44 ğŸ’ª Building Inner Strength through Hard Work - Building inner strength requires relentless hard work. - No shortcuts or magic pills, only consistent effort. 46:31 ğŸ§  Understanding the Anterior Mid-Cingulate Cortex - The anterior mid-cingulate cortex is a brain structure associated with willpower. - It grows when people do things they don't want to do, adding friction. 56:36 ğŸ’¡ Discovering Your True Self - Many people feel like they're missing something in life because they haven't unlocked their true potential. - Self-examination, willpower, courage, and determination are keys to self-discovery. 01:01:31 ğŸ§  Building Willpower and Inner Strength - Be vulnerable, how do you wanna be remembered?  personal opinion note I feel like he is the extreme embodiment of hustling, but it doesn't mean we have to be him. I take it more as learn from his life and his discipline lessons you can use for yourself, not a complete roadmap of how to live life. Most of that map isn't for certain and is for us to experience in reality and decide what to do. So for me, I will use his life lessons for the hard times in life and finding that extra resolve and energy within me when I know I gotta do something no matter small. But I'm not gonna be spending every waking hour hustling, only a designated time (example 30 min in the morning lemme go through my emails and to do list from the previous day, 30 minutes warm up figure drawing, then 1-3 hours illustration with breaks in between for stretching, cardio to keep myself woken up, and small walks around the block)  without distraction to do something well everyday. When doing the chores or catching up with someone maintaining friendships. I'd say its more keeping yourself accountable and watching how you change over time instead of letting everything happen passively.  To surmise, find what works for you from role models that you feel envious of being or find some connection with. To paraphrase Trystan Lee since I liked this quote, "if it works for you, it works." Same with Goggins if it works for him it works. There's always another way of doing things but find what works for you.   All that being said (@ 58:26 rn) I agree that its a harsh truth but by far a lesson I'm learning everyday that hard times build a person. The stuff that sucks that you don't know how to do or might have set you back a ton in reality or in your mind is what hurts but also shapes you. Its the act of accepting your current reality, having an inner dialogue with yourself both understanding but also objectively, and  overcoming those things or learning how to do those things that you'll grow. With art, finding how you don't know how to do some fundamental and are scared of starting cuz you might mess up, but accepting that's where I am and I may fail but I'll learn from that failure and get better. Or maybe I will do it and I'm just afraid of failure in itself. Regardless I won't know until I start and try it. So I agree with that. "The problem is you, and you don't wanna fix it."   Belief versus proof of action. Just like with hell week, people will yell at you and call you the worst of things, maybe shove you around make you go through the worst of it. But continuing through those hard times is what shows you that you're capable. You are capable. Even when it hurts or all the dominoes fall down, the game isn't over.   Focus on one thing at a time don't multitask to give your all to that one thing. If you're gonna mess around then do that fully, don't be between work and your fun. If you're working then focus on just that.   Be you, aim towards something rather than running from stuff and saying what you are not.  Your inner dialogue is a two way street between that voice and how you respond to it. There's a time and place for all actions and emotions.   Teach yourself how to fail properly. Victory is laid in a continuous process of failures.

Respect to him, but must say I have a different perspective. For me it's about the journey, NOT the goal. Everyone always asks "what is your goal in life?". I think it's the wrong question to ask. A better question is "What journey in life do you want to go on?". The reason I think this is better is because most of your life is a journey, so you better enjoy the journey!   Let's say your goal is to reach top of Mount Everest. Does it REALLY matter if you reach the top? For me, I'm happy to go half way, I still enjoyed the journey. The goal, lasts maybe one day, the journey can be weeks or months.  I'm writing a book at the moment. I'm enjoying the journey. Do I need a goal that the book has to be out in 6 months, or it needs so many readers or be a best seller? No!  If you enjoy the journey, quite often a successful by product will happen naturally, but pressuring yourself to have a painful journey to meet a goal is looking at life from the wrong angle. Just my opinion.

I am what David would call a "regular guy". 33 Years old, happily married, great job, financially secure, friends, family, decent health (not obese), no drug problems, and no problems in general. Since the age 22 I  felt like something is missing. Like I am living a mediocre life and not pushing myself to attain what many religions, philosophers and great minds consider to be what is destined for man. Not "man" in inverted commas who lives his life based on reactions to external influences, but one who is truly in control of his faculties and lays out a definite course for his own life.   This goal which I have set for myself has mainly come as a result of the study of the different religions of the world and esoteric subjects and I have no interest in the motivational speaker grind-set mentality. I have come to the realization through my studies that, to achieve my goal, I have to be merciless with myself and lead a life that many would consider miserable. This effort is required not only to reach spiritual goals but also to achieve what I consider to be worldly goals (such as learning a new language, improving my physique or excelling at my job).    I clicked on this video by chance and it is my first time seeing David Goggins, which I have consciously avoided because I considered him as part of the grindset motivational speakers. How surprised I was to hear him express, almost verbatim, the rigorous effort required every day without the feel-good mumbo jumbo. What he says aligns perfectly with the wisdom of the ages without him being over-philosophizing or being religious.   I commend this man and encourage those who dare to walk the path of what I consider to be what God, or nature (whatever your convictions), has destined for man - the man without inverted commas.

As a clinical psychologist, I'd love to give this guy therapy. He's helped me a lot and I wish I could return the favor. He's still suffering in ways he doesn't need to suffer, in ways that only take away from his greatness, not add to it. I hope he finds his way out from underneath the demons that pile on him every day. I don't think they're required anymore.  This to all ya'll who try to follow Goggins' advice and continually fail: wounds can sometimes propel people to greatness, though less often goodness. More often, they putrefy and poison your mind and spirit, your interactions, your relationships.   Some people are sharpened by fighting themselves.... and the thing about fighting yourself, is that the one you're fighting never goes away. They're always with you. David Goggins says this in different words. He's always fighting himself.  Real talk, I don't see this work very often. Way, way more often I see people blunted by fighting themselves. Down. Hopeless. Ashamed because they can't 'get it', can't beat themselves. Any idea how often an addict tries to gain sobriety using the stick? Almost always. How often do they get sober doing that? Not never, but almost.   Neither of these people are at peace. One of them just has more to show for it. But what if you could be at peace, and be great at what you are called to do? Hell, what if you could actually do what you're called to do, instead of what you're compelled to do so that you're 'enough' and 'worthy'? What if you could rest without immediately reverting to the worst, most wounded version of yourself?  Stay hard, that's the mantra. A mountain is hard. Stones are hard. Both are ground to dust by the soft persistence of water and wind.   Surrender, surrender, surrender. Peace. It's what the Bible is about, the Heart Sutra, The Bhagavad Gita, The Tao te Ching. Set yourself free and see what greatness (and goodness) follows.

I'm not a super big fan of Mr.Goggins but I respect him and I appreciate his way of expressing his feelings and thoughts of the concept of discipline. I don't know him personally. I don't know how (and why) he became this public figure that he is now and I don't know if he is real or just trying to have succes in the "motivation realm". I dont know this and I hope thats not the case but the internet could be a weird place and full of hypocrites. I don't trust people on the internet, even if they are famous. But, whatever if Mr.goggins narrativd its real and honest or not, some of the things he is saying seems interesting and I would like to share my thoughts.  First, I love how he express himself about discipline because It seems very real. Discipline its just doing whatever you have to do. I agree with that. Its very simple concept but its hard to implement (and usually sucks, its a struggle). I agree. But, on the other hand, I feel that he is very hard or strong with his approach, a little extreme. I think that you have to know when you need discipline and suck it. But also you have to know that not everything its discipline. Being relaxed and confort its not a bad thing. You just have to know when its time for each thing. You have to be flexible and goggins seems to me a little inflexible in this aspect. Sometimes I feel like maybe he has an obssesion with discipline and if he is happy and its help him, good for him, but I'm not pretty sure if this approach it's healthy in the long run. I dont think obssesions are good. Having the power of being discipline, I consider this something incredible useful and healthy but also you have to learn to being relaxed and in comfort. For some people being relaxed it's is hard because they feel guilty for not being like grinding or being strong.  The "always grinding mindset" I think its pretty popular today, at least in motivational videos in youtube. I dont feel this is good and maybe Mr.Goggins sometimes transmits (to me) that vibes.  Second. Mr.Goggins seems to see things in binary terms. You are a loser (someone without discipline, I guess) or you are a winner. Like I wrote before, I feel like its pretty extreme and I dont feel its a good idea. Things are not so easy. You can have a bad day, being less discipline, even have a lazy week... And what? You are a loser for that? Why? I think its absurd. Until you die, you can change, you have an option. You will change when you have to, when its time. If you get change quickly, beautiful, if not, okey. Life its an experience not a test. The "I'm a loser" mentality I feel its a very unproductive way of thinking, maybe even sick way for your own mind. What its the benefit ot blaming and punishing other people or even ourselver for not being discipline X amount time? Maybe you could use blame to have the fire inside you to make the step you need, to have discipline. But it just a little time. I don't feel like Mr.goggins use it in that kind of way.  Third, I love his explanation of his struggles. Even what his problems, he tried to change and It seems like it went good. I really appreciate that. Sometimes I feel like he is enfatize a lot his childhood and his problems to read/write and I get weird vibes with this because I feel like: what he is trying to selling me? Why he enfatize this a lot? But I don't know, Its just the esceptic in me.  Whatever. I have to watch another hour of this podcast but I want it to write some of my thoughts. Thank you Mr hubberman for sharing thing with subtitles (I'm deaf and they are useful). Also thank you Mr.Goggins for sharing thoughts. Wish you thr best with your journet. Lots a love and health for all! Happy new year!

I admire Goggins and think that I understand his point of view, but if you apply what Paul Conti says in his book about trauma to what Goggins says, it begs the question, what is compassion, then, and why should we be willing to give less compassion when the receiving end are ourselves? I genuinely don't know the answer to these questions and absolutely would take Goggin's approach on many stances, maybe more than 50% of times, cause there's no evidence either that there should be balance or that balance means this or that percentage, but, still, what then becomes the line on the sand, the standard, the clue for when to beat us up, or other people, for that matter, to makes us a better person and find all the answers and for when not letting a subordinate, a relative, a young or an old person, or anyone really, run when they are injured? Life is always complicated and there's no one size fits all solution for anything. I agree, in this sense, with him that thereÂ´s no hacking! We have got to figure out everything and these tips we receive from any guest, from Andrew himself, from books we read, from growing up lessons and inner voices are just pieces of a puzzle or part of other structures, which we must define as well. In Goggin's case, it's  clear that he is a very tough person with himself, as if he were two people, and the person who steps up to talk to us in his interviews and books is the one imposing and assessing behaviours. He won't let the other one come up, he keeps this one away with all the swearing, making him feel ashamed for being vulnerable. And we tend to watch this and admire him for putting himself through such hardships. Ok, I agree with it most of the time, but can't help thinking, would I do the same with my children, with people that in my understanding might have had suffering enough without the same opportunities I've had to learn how to cope, and finally how do I know that what I need is always to go running injured, is there never a time to be compassionate with myself? What I mean is, Paul Conti and David Goggins apparently have opposite views on what to do with trauma and I can only tell you that I see value in both and can never step down from how much complicated life is.
How does Goggins find comfort, outside of conquering? Morsels of comfort, i guess

Iâ€™m all for pushing through adversity but some people might need a softer approach in the beginning and know we are just wired differently, not stupid, not less, not lazy, and no this isnâ€™t any woke affirmation BS. It is about learning how to learn in our own way and taking advantage of our particular wiring. Compound it with Atomic Habits by James Clear.  I wish you all a great 2024. May this year be the trigger to start on the path of your best self.

Though what David Goggins is saying makes sense to me yet I feel he is missing a piece of the puzzle. I completely understand where he is coming from and what it took for him to build himself. It's really commendable. Yet I feel something's amiss. I am not judging David at all. God knows I have so many flaws. And his message has came at great timing for me and I intend to implement it. Yet I think there should be a balance between the masculine and feminine aspects of life. I am not talking about gender but the masculine and feminine qualities within each one of us. So there's a place for the tough love and pushing yourself (which is infact very important) and there's also place for compassion and kindness towards self. And both should balance out each other. That would be a holistic approach in my opinion, to lead a life with family, kids and society and also achieve great personal success. I am grateful for having received David's message today and I wish him well.

I've had this on loop for two days. It got me off my ass and running in -1â„ƒ at 5am for the first time since September last year, managed 8km, then gym on the bike. I've been a borderline alcoholic/smoker for 15 years, Goggins got me running initially, I managed 26kms back in October '22, and I've broken my spine, and got jacked up knees and ankles. I regressed to a piece of shit alcoholic again in the last 2 years, but hearing this and understanding what I hadn't heard before about pushing through the injuries and pain because if you don't, you'll regress, that's the most relatable real shit I've heard from him. If I'm not running and going to the gym, my demons fester and I'm drinking and smoking that day, and will likely be dead in 10 years. That's worth pushing through any injury even if it means limping, learning ways to overcome at all cost, because the alternative is not an option any more. If you relate, give this a like and strap your fucking shoes on. Let's get after it, our life depends on it. Much love.

I'm ADD and ADHD , learning disabled , had an IEP, etc . totally felt David when he was talking about his learning process with new info that wasn't absorbed easily.  . I had a really hard time with my schooling,  but the worst was when i went to Hebrew school ,  i just couldn't get it , and the teachers back then didn't understand learning disabilities in general , let alone after school hebrew instructors.  i stressed so much , it got to the point where i just would tape record , and memorize , vs really being able to read the language.  i felt like i was faking it ,  and it really caused a distancing until i was an adult , from the religion .  Kids now are so lucky to have a better support system  , the advances since the 80's/90's have been massive .   the best thing for kids like us , is for people to be supportive of their passions and push that , over specific standard school studies.   My mom was a great teacher , but also my biggest advocate , and representative.  without her id have been tossed into special ed and that wasn't who i was/am .  She did that for all her kids ( students )  . and i wish David had someone in his life when he was younger . but also get being your own biggest critic.   no ones harder on us , than we are to ourselves .   Can also speak on that what we do understand , and have passion for , we excel , and are hyper aware , deeply invested , have a lot of initiative and will overwork as an outlet  , and have great situational awareness  .  .  i wish i could have lunch with David sometime .  wish my Uncle was still around , he was an old timer ultrathon runner based out of AZ and CO  , he used to train with Pam Reed and was on her team for years , and he used to do Leadville , and the Rim race ,  Blackwater , etc. .  his name was Benny Linkhart . was a great man .

This is an incredibly fascinating interview:   Unsurprisingly, as Andrew Huberman has alluded to, David Goggin's has a mental process that is not at all new. In particular, it has existed in western therapies for childhood trauma (recently "invented") and eastern "spiritual" practices. Notably,  (therapy) internal family systems; a style of therapy that conceptualizes your inside as wounded and protective parts, that are led by the core self. the more traumatized you are, the more distinct these parts become. at the extremes, you have "dissociative identity disorder". when each voice is speaking, the other voices actually don't remember. it's not even distinct voices, it's fractured identities. The therapy works in managing the dialogue between these parts and the core self. the core self is supposed to embody, in part, the values you want to manifest. the core part, i believe, is what you see as "goggins", who also relays what the other parts are saying. heavily recommend you look into this NO MATTER who you are, if you are interested in cultivating greater awareness and becoming more like goggins. awareness and introspection is always the firsrt step. this is easier in the presence of a compassionate witness (a good therapist).   (practice/philsophy) buddhism: The buddha, muuch like goggins, had a long period of self introspection where by he realized things about the nature of the mind. One big realization, as andrew huberman mentions towards the last ten minutes of this interview, is that emotions are all just phenomenom. you don't need to act on them. they're nothing "real", you don't need to distract yourselves from them (the way an alcoholic might distract from heartbreak or failure by relapsing, or binge eat, etc). Goggins speaks of people who are scared of their internal world "lowly", and talks about how introspection is key. andrew huberman mentions meditation as a key practice for self awareness. buddhism is a framework that exemplifies this sort of introspection.   There's many other "methods" that are very close to what goggin's describes that encourages introspection. This includes  - somatic experiencing (therapy)  - compasssionate inquiry (therapy) which i don't want to go into detail on.   In any case, it's clear through this interview that 1. mastering your internal world so that 2. you can act with laser focus towards one goal (goggins is willpower. yours doesn't have to be). is the key to goggin-esque success.   good luck.

I wonder if there is a connection between what viral figures from the "childhood trauma" camp like gabor mate or ranjan chatterjee would say about david goggins mental process.   In these camps, a lot of the focus, as far as i understand, isÂ  1. compassionate observation (without habitual/unconscious action) of your emotions/thoughts (for people with childhood truama like david goggins, whose father beat him, it's likely dominated by self critical chatter). You don't just notice the voices, and notice how they drive you to addictive behaviors like binge eating, drugs, work, etc. You also look for the meaning. i.e. "I have these voices because my father did this to me. the voices and what they say are not who i am, they are what PART OF ME learned to say to myself to survive".  2. action with awareness: as you cultivate awareness, you'll catch yourself as you reach for that donut, go for the blunt, reach for the alcohol. in those moments, you simply realize, "Oh, I'm trying to cope with my voices again". in this space of awareness, you chose to do "the right thing", whatever that is. You need to learn what "the right thing" is, intellectually, so that at these moments, while being hit by negative voices and emotions, you can still tell yourself what to do,   Simple as it may be, this is a multi year/decade process. In particular, they emphasize that the negative voices and feelings never really go away. You just learn to coexist.Â these camps are heavily influenced by the buddha.   Funny enough, the buddha and goggins has many similarities. The buddha, like david goggins, was extremely introspective. he spent some years early in his life heavily observing his mind. He came to realizations, then spent time teaching a few heavily interested people to cultivate what he has learned. Funny enough, this sounds a lot like goggins. many people are drawn to the end result of, for goggins, being an invincible highly motivated man, and for the buddha, someone who is fine with everything that happens (equanimity). Just as for the buddha, Goggins also has only met a few people who he thinks really "gets it". Goggins is like the modern day buddha, who instead of dissolving inner voices, spent decades cultivating an extremely tailored inner voice: it's tailored to the specific self critical voice that he learned in his infancy/childhood due to an abusive father and for the society he lives in that praises accomplishment/individualism.   I'd say, start meditating. properly. observe your mind. figure out who you want to become. create an inner dialogue that allows you to take actions that consistently bring you to what you want to be.   Goggins manifests the essence of willpower. Due to his history, he fights his subconscious critical voice with a conscious angry/driven voice. You may not need this. and you can pursue the essence of any quality you want. Just as goggins says, he decided to paint the image of david goggins and create that. Don't try to create yourself in the image of goggins, try to find who you want to be.   tbh. I think goggins is overidentifying with the angry voice he created to counter his childhood voice. I don't really understand the purpose of "not losing the willpower" all the way up until he dies. The voice served a purpose in getting him out of his slump. It serves a purpose now by inspiring people who are where he was. but he holds onto the voice as his identity. I think it is beginning to outstay its usefulness. His body is breaking down, I wonder how he is as a father (i truly don't now), etc. It's all very interesting. this was an excellent interview. well done.

The Chimp Paradox explores the concept of an internalized impediment hindering the realization of our goals. By actively resisting distractions and challenges, such as those encountered in the pursuit of difficult tasks, we fortify our willpower. This approach, exemplified by individuals like David Goggins, underscores the notion that confronting disliked activities contributes to the enhancement of one's resolve, progressively diminishing the influence of the internal 'chimp'. What I do every time the chimp in my head tries to stop me from doing something challenging, I say â€œfuck youâ€ to the chimp in my head, it really doesnâ€™t like that. The more you do this the less itâ€™ll try to stop you. Just my own personal experience. Iâ€™m no scientist. The only science lessons I have ever had is from the Huberman lab. â¤

I am having such trouble grasping the concept of 'friction'... let me just put an everyday example: we have leakage in our basement. To prevent the basement from flooding, we have to drain 2 wells every 4 hours. I dont like to drain the wells, because it is outside, the weather is shit etc., but I do WANT to do it, because I would find it even more unpleasant when the basement floods. So does emptying the wells grow my willpower?

David Goggins is not crazy, and I actually believe that like my father, he is a genius that underestimates his own ability due to academic perspective yet actually got through life somehow (will to grow). My father and that side of the family is what I see as pure 'will'. So much abuse, poverty, neglect, crime, all of that and did something about it. I genuinely think David Goggins just needs to learn how to learn, because learning is a skill you can learn to do as well when it comes to academics, and as someone who would try to help people in school I was more like his wife who could grasp it instantly but not be able to explain it and that was what I trained my inner dialogue to do as well, working on language to be able to explain conceptually and now I'm able to literally teach this friend I met in group therapy how to learn so he could do well on his finals, like man we are the most adaptable vertebrates on the planet (i hope thats a safe assumption to make), consciousness itself IS will, mind is will, and being able to manipulate your own mind to see different perspectives, gain metacognition/self awareness of ones own thought processes, and make change is something David Goggins has done exceptionally well, I hope in the academic domain he can learn to creatively conceptualize, that would be hilarious to see David in the future fully articulate exactly everything he knows to those who just dont 'get it' because language is just another barrier for us to overcome and understand to effectively communicate one's own perspective. I can only call it destiny that I share a birthday with him and Jordan, just gives me more drive to impact the amount of people they have as well. Mind is the precursor to reality, manipulating your mind enables you to manipulate reality, and David is the clearest, most blatant example we have of that today.

Thank you for offering such a content free of charge.. My summary: Introduction to David Goggins: Described as a retired Navy SEAL, ultramarathon runner, Guinness World Record holder, and best-selling author. Achieved induction into the International Sports Hall of Fame for athletic accomplishments. Inner Strength and Self-Discipline:   Focuses on Goggins' mindset and inner dialogue, emphasizing daily self-discipline and intense self-dialogue to achieve goals. Discussion around the psychological and scientific aspects underlying willpower. Work Ethic and Struggles:  Highlights Goggins' approach to learning and his relentless work ethic, emphasizing the effort and struggle required in everything he does. Discusses the challenges faced during his weight loss journey and struggles with Navy SEAL training. Passion, Emotion, and Experience:  Shows Goggins' passion and intensity, especially when discussing his journey and reflecting on his experiences. Touches upon the impact of emotions, actions as manifestations of the mind, and the importance of experiences in shaping perspectives. Discipline and Daily Mental Training:  Discusses Goggins' daily mental training, mentioning his approach to mental exercises and self-improvement. Mentions Goggins' engagement in science and medicine, his study routines, and his meticulous approach to learning. Podcast Sponsorship and Supplements:  Includes sponsor mention about Maui Nui Venison and its nutrient-dense properties. Goggins' viewpoint on supplements as a small fraction compared to the importance of lifestyle habits and actions. Mindfulness, Art, and Brain Training:  Discusses Goggins' analogy of painting in the mind daily, indicating the importance of mental work and creativity. Encourages audience engagement, suggestions, and feedback for the Huberman Lab podcast. Supplement Recommendations:  Advises on exploring Live Momentous for supplement information mentioned in the podcast related to sleep, hormones, and focus.

Hi Andrew, thanks for all your content. I wanted to share a quick story that I feel is relevant to your friend who is overweight and you asked for David's advice to him. I loved that. It's hard, what can we say to that person.   When I was a young kid I had a birthday party and having a victim mindset, I was upset at something my friends had done... "to me." They were probably just having a good time. I threw a fit, and my mom tried to console me saying something along the lines that I was only hurting myself. I knew she was 100% correct. Like David said, we know what the truth is.  I've reflected on that many times over the years. I believe I was addicted to that specific negative sensation of not feeling good enough. The feeling is what is important, but if I had to label it, I was afraid I wasn't good enough.   I've shared it with some friends and although painful, it has seemed to be accurate enough to help people grow.

Hey dr huberman, got a question for ya. Most meditation practices aim for awareness in the moment by simply observing internal and external stimuli, and that seems to put people in a state of contentment in that moment. Assuming this awareness could be brought to every second of your life, wouldn't it be possible for one to be satisfied with that moment no matter what, due to the lack of well, thinking. It's paradoxical in the sense that a way of contentment can only be brought by the lack of thinking and by pure observation, yet people chase the same feeling by doing the exact opposite, working with the future in mind, in the present. In a case where basic survival needs are met, what does this say about the human tendency to Long for a certain ideal in the future? What does the science say behind this feeling of satisfaction due to awareness?

A common misconception about ADD: the impairment is in the inability to switch focus rapidly back and forth, it's not the inability to focus (or hyperfocus). What I hear Gogging say is he has removed all distractions and choses to ignore / not address all at once, in order to be able to accomplish anything. That's how he's "trained" himself "out of ADD" as Andrew suggests - he does it by dealing with it. Repeating until it sinks in (which takes much longer for us with ADD when not intrinsically interested in the object of attention). So again, David's structure isn't now suddenly built in a way so he doesn't have to deal with ADD -- he's just learned to deal with it, and it takes work every time.

You donâ€™t know me son !!!! I relate so much to Goggins. My dad and mom both smoked crack when I was a child. They were very psychically abusive and both died when I was ten. My grandma died a mouth later. I was thrown in a group home from the age 10 to 18. I was in special ed and they said I was emotionally disturbed and learning disabled, which is something easy to be when your parents beat the hell out of you as I kid... Then I was homeless in my early 20s.  When Andrew said, Goggins had no one to shield him from the world as a youngster, I could so relate to that, when you have no protection from the world - it makes you extremely tough. Fast forward 20 years later, I have two masters, a brown belt in jujitsu, two licenses in my profession ( clinical social work) and have two great young sons I pour all my love into. Ironically enough I still feel very unaccomplished and still push myself as if I'm homeless and a messed up abused child. I also relate to Goggins when he said his rich friends always come to him and say "I'm missing something". I always tell them you look for your wealth to bring you happiness but it will never bring you true happiness. It will buy you nice things, but until you really live for who you are, nothing matters.

In therapy and life coaching there is this instrument called "tactical spite" which if appropriately applied in the correct context and situation, is very powerful and constructive. Whenever people (from the crab bucket) say you are not able to do something because of reasons, then some people weaponize that talk to show them wrong, by doing it anyway, successfully. For crabs in the bucket and for gatekeepers of the higher layers, this breaking beyond the preset confines is terrifying. But for mutual-growth oriented supportive friends, this growth  is an  awesome thing to see. In  both his audiobooks, Goggins gives options to adapt to your own needs and your own path, explicitly telling the listener or reader, to not follow his. Create your own flavor of progress.

Okay, this is my top 5 favorite episodes

The part on inspiration, character, and self image is very interesting. As kid who grew up mostly without a father figure, I remember vividly using the same mechanism, especially around teenagehood. I would pick up parts of fictional characters to build up and ideal version of what a man had to be; of the man I wanted and needed to be. This ideal is one of the most important thing that helped me keep my head above the water. Just like Goggins - even though maybe not to the same extent - I can't say that I was born with the brain of an academic. Most of my school years were a pain in the ass. Yet, through consistent work and with the support of my parents, I am now a masters student in Philosophy. I haven't had to make it all alone like Goggins did, but I can relate on the feeling of building one's identity, a process that's highly important especially as men. A friend of mine, who's a university teacher in psychology, once said to me that it was a miracle that I could develop the way I did considering the childhood I had. She's probably right, but we are living proofs that it's always possible to make it.  Thank you for sharing your story and thank you to Dr Huberman for making this deeper dive in Mr D. Goggins life.

Summary -still worth watching.   Overcome Adversity Through Self-Discipline: Embrace life's challenges as opportunities for growth, using them to build resilience and mental toughness.   Internal Dialogue is Crucial: Cultivate a strong, positive internal dialogue. The way you talk to yourself significantly influences your actions and outcomes.   No Excuses Mentality: Adopt a no-excuses approach to life, focusing on hard work and dedication to achieve your goals.   Confront Yourself: Regular self-confrontation is necessary for personal growth. It's crucial to face your vulnerabilities and weaknesses head-on.   Relentless Pursuit of Goals: Pursue personal objectives relentlessly, without seeking external motivation or shortcuts.   Discipline and Repetition for Learning: Overcome learning challenges (like ADD/ADHD) through disciplined study and repetitive practice.   Authenticity Over Superficiality: Be authentic in your life, especially on social media, and avoid superficial portrayals of your journey.   Acceptance of Lifeâ€™s Difficulties: Recognize and accept the difficulties of life as an integral part of personal development and growth.

If I remember correctly from your willpower/tenacity video, wasn't there a difference between being aware of the fact you're going to do something you don't want to do, and being "forced" too,   What I mean is, wasn't there a difference between feeling helpless or something similar, and having the intention of doing something you perhaps did not want to do, where you get more of the positive physiological and or mental responses, as opposed to just the negative?   For instance, is there a difference between lets say your hot water heater is damaged/malfunctioning whatever, but you need to shower immediately to prepare for something and leave within 10 minutes, and now you need to take a quick cold shower, and you hate the idea of it, but you are unaware of the idea of this being a potentially beneficial act?   (Or what if you planned on your shower being an attempt of cold water exposure that morning anyway, you could even be completely unaware of the fact you don't have hot water?)  So would that fall more into the category of "negative" stress, and would it still positivity affect the growth of your AMSC? Or is that out of the window because you're just hating this moment and idea and see no positive angle here, it's just a frustration?  Sorry if this seems scattered/poorly worded, but what I'm saying is, and I'm trying to consider your other guest, Anna Crumbes work on mindset here, if I remember correctly she had mentioned if you're lets say considering the more "negative" aspects of stress, you're more likely to suffer from the negative consequences,   as opposed to focusing on the more "positive" physiological responses, you're more likely to have a positive outcome.  So if I'm only considering the negative aspects of stress, (let's say my mindset/only reference of Stress is hyperfocusing on all the negative aspects) Seeing how that's all I am aware of in that moment, I'm possibly leaving "money on the table" so to speak, and missing an opportunity to benefit from something, possibly even just causing harm even to myself instead?  I'll have to finish/rewatch the other videos, but the human body is so fascinating, it's the same moment in time and your perspective on the "issue" could possibly dictate completely different outcomes and effects on your health, etc.

I've been wanting someone to ask David how he deals with studying while having ADHD. Physical training was always something I enjoyed. Pushing myself physically to exhaustion is so much easier than mentally studying a book for hours only to finish a few pages trying to comprehend and remember what I studied. Medication helps a little, but my damn mind is constantly wandering. Took me 8 damn years to finish college XD. I studied Fire Science, EMT, marketing, business administration, CIS, and economics because I couldn't figure out what I wanted to do. I passed my classes by building good relationships with my teachers and talking about my ADHD struggles. Finally finished College last May, thinking I'd be done with books, and now I'm studying Cyber Security and literally handwriting the book page by page to pass the certification exams I need to take. Thank you, Professor Huberman, for the awesome podcast!

I found the bit where David was addressing his anger very interesting. While I have found David extremely motivating and am grateful for the lessons he has learned and expressed to others, there was always a vibe of anger or some form of discontentment there. Perhaps it is because I am very different from that, a warm-hearted, gentle, and kind person. David says he knows what is bad for him and what is good, and that he has anger that will never go away. Maybe he is right and that is powerful to know yourself in that way, but part of me thinks the anger can be addressed and learned from. It's an interesting concept. Are there things about us that we can't change even if we want to? I'm not convinced that's true.

I was thinking about this brain structure and the possible evolutionary reasons for why it behaves in such a way. 'Friction' is correlated to work, and works can improve things. So it make sence for an animal that does a lot of work, and therefore goes through a lot of friction, to live a longer life, it is advantageous for the species because more things gets built. As opposed to an animal that is simply sitting arround, consuming resources. Evolutionary speaking, it would be advantageous for the species if the animals that go thorugh a lot of friction to live longer, and the ones that avoid friction live shorter lives, resources would be distributed more optimally.

David Goggins + Andrew Huberman is a lethal combo when it comes to my personal development. In my mind I call the two of them David Gugerman :') I respect the combination of them the most.  I could relate with Goggins his message in previous shorts/clips/videos, but I found the way he messaged it too rash and therefore unnuanced. I've taken more unnuanced advice to heart in the past and it always has hurt more than help more. So I was always wary to go fully all in, and to do David Goggins advice for like 50%, I wouldn't see how that would work. Andrew Huberman is his nuance. Knowing what the anterior mid cingulate cortex (aka The Cookie Monster) does is amazingly helpful to nuance David Goggins his advice. I can now fully go all in.  The nuance is to be wary of the "suck worship" trap.  The will of the warrior needs to be present, knowing what to do is always there, and if it sucks then embrace it. This is the path that this podcast is inspiring me to take, which is slightly different than what I'm hearing from David Goggins. David Goggins gives me the impression to always embrace the suck. He paints the picture that the suck is always there. For me, it isn't always there. It's there often, but by far not always. I wonder if David Goggins sees that since his whole life seems to suck (which I doubt since he must have had beautiful moments too and it seems he doesn't expand on how the suck relates to the beautiful parts in life). I think there's a danger to that which I call "suck workship". I think the suck shouldn't be worshipped but respected. One shouldn't always want to be in a state of suck but simply know to their bones that when the going gets tough then IT'S ON! And when it's on, it's time to take some souls. The mentality here is a life or death mentality.  I think one should strife to do their best in life. Sometimes that can feel good, and sometimes it can feel bad. No matter how it feels: do it. Whenever I listen to David Goggins his message feels more like "always choose the path with more pain" and to that I can't relate. Pain doesn't always lead to growth. Going for what you want with humility and dealing with all the obstacles in the way, that leads to growth. In many cases, the fact that it sucks is an obstacle that needs to be cleared. Sometimes it doesn't have to suck though, and that's okay too. I wonder what David Goggins thinks of that, because if he agrees with me then that part of his message gets lost. Not every important thing worth fighting for is an arduous path of torture.   Sometimes, the most important things worth fighting for is more like a nice hike in the Swiss alps with your loved ones. It still takes effort, but I mean come on.  Hiking.  In Switzerland.  With loved ones! It's beautiful to do that, let's fucking go, 100% all in. Goal cleared in no time.   Trying to always find and embrace the suck is in my opinion yet another small form of comfort seeking. To me it seems that suck sucks the most when it comes unexpected. There's a small type of comfort in when the suck is expected by always seeking it out for example. To be able to deal with the unexpected suck, I believe that I should train my equanimity (I do it by meditation but I could also do it by working out or studying hard or doing something emotionally hard).   In both cases (whether doing something sucks or doesn't), the message I've received in this podcast is to always have the inner warrior present. Since in essence it's always about life or death. And to this Goggins gives a clear thought: "thinking like that is way out there for most people, it's insane to them." Here he rejects "the common man". Knowing that he does confronted me with that thought and made me reflect, and I agree with him based on my own experiences. I know personally that when things are felt that sharply (life or death type of thinking), then I become unstoppable. I know in CBT that this is a cognitive distortion (it's all or nothing thinking). Yet, here David clearly shows that this type of thinking is what has helped him. And I do think that CBT categorizing "all or nothing" thinking always as a bad thing seems overblown to me. All or nothing thinking has pros and cons to it, and the people that need CBT seem to be suffering from the cons too much. The pro is that it fires me up as it does to David. That is a big pro.  I have a suspicion that to David Goggins it also always is about life or death, but I might be projecting a bit too much now. In any case, the point I got from Goggins is that one has to fight to self-actualize (as if they're fighting for their life). Sometimes that fight is easy, sometimes it's hard, but without that mentality, self-actualization can become difficult because of one's inability to embrace the suck. Maslow said: "What one can be, one must be!" If one can't embrace the suck then one can't self-actualize.   Like Wim Hof says "the cold is my friend". The message I got here is "the suck is my friend, and when it's around, it's time to take some souls." Sounds extreme? Yep, but when thinking about this podcast I'm clearly getting the message that this is what it takes to get to where I need to be. And I agree.
