00:58 Despite a difficult upbringing, obesity, and low prospects in his 20s, Goggins transformed his life through an inner dialogue that led to becoming a Navy SEAL, ultramarathon runner, and successful author. 01:53 The podcast explores the unique inner dialogue Goggins engages in for self-discipline, delving into the mindset, scientific aspects of willpower, and his current pursuits, including studying medicine. 04:18 Sponsors of the podcast include Maui Nui Venison, AeroPress, and Eight Sleep, each contributing to the episode's production. 08:07 Goggins is commended for embodying discipline and tackling hard challenges. The conversation highlights his current focus on learning and studying, particularly in the field of medicine. 13:51 Goggins reflects on his struggle with ADHD and the process of teaching himself how to focus, expressing empathy for others facing learning disabilities. 19:30 Goggins discusses the constant friction and challenges he faces daily, emphasizing that everything he does requires a high level of effort and dedication. 21:23 David Goggins reflects on his challenging background, physical limitations, and military disqualifications, emphasizing the importance of overcoming obstacles through relentless effort and focus. 27:35 Goggins reveals the haunting impact of his difficult past, detailing the mental and emotional challenges he faced in trying to overcome societal judgments, racism, and personal limitations. 37:01 The conversation explores Goggins' relentless pursuit of self-improvement, highlighting the absence of positive reinforcement ("all stick, no carrot") and the continuous internal battle he faces to prove himself wrong. 39:50 Goggins delves into the constant self-doubt he battles, particularly during challenging moments, and how he must consistently outwork his own negative self-perceptions to succeed. 41:14 Goggins emphasizes the absence of a "get out of jail free card" in his journey, advocating for the mindset of "stay hard" and the necessity to outwork one's inherent limitations to achieve personal growth. 46:31 The anterior mid-cingulate cortex, a brain structure, grows when individuals engage in activities they don't want to do. It's linked to willpower, challenges, and overcoming adversity. 48:25 The key to developing the anterior mid-cingulate cortex is consistently doing things that are hard and uncomfortable, not just more of what you enjoy. Friction, discomfort, and facing challenges are essential. 55:11 The lack of friction, challenge, and struggle can negatively impact individuals, even those born into wealth. Goggins emphasizes the importance of the "stick" and being haunted to drive personal growth. 01:00:04 The anterior mid-cingulate cortex gets activated when the body is pushed to move despite resistance. It's associated with the dopamine reward pathway, indicating that pain and friction can trigger a sense of accomplishment and pleasure. 01:05:44 David Goggins discusses the plasticity of the brain and emphasizes the concept of "no days off" to facilitate personal growth. 01:07:29 Goggins criticizes the prevalence of mediocrity, expressing frustration at people's reluctance to put in the necessary work to improve their lives. 01:10:48 Goggins discusses the tendency of people to attribute past success to external conditions, highlighting the importance of recognizing personal responsibility. 01:11:44 The conversation shifts to addressing the difficulty people face in making positive changes in their lives, particularly in areas like weight loss. 01:13:04 Goggins challenges individuals who resist change, emphasizing that they need to create a false reality to overcome mental and physical obstacles. 01:14:27 Goggins warns against relying solely on external sources for motivation, stressing the importance of self-exploration and examining one's internal desires. 01:15:25 Reflecting on his weight loss journey, Goggins highlights the ongoing struggle and emphasizes the harsh reality that positive change is challenging and uncomfortable. 01:17:44 Goggins shares examples of friends who made significant positive changes in their lives after a single conversation, underscoring the role of self-criticism in triggering transformation. 01:20:36 The discussion touches on personal weaknesses, such as procrastination, and Goggins emphasizes the need to start immediately, irrespective of the time. 01:26:20 David Goggins emphasizes the sacrifices he makes for success, including lack of sleep and unconventional lifestyle choices, driven by his determination to maintain his inner strength. 01:26:50 David Goggins discusses the challenge of balancing discipline in relationships, highlighting the tension between personal goals and the needs of loved ones. He emphasizes the importance of clear communication about individual priorities. 01:31:28 Goggins reflects on past mistakes of compromising himself to please others, emphasizing the importance of being true to oneself and not sacrificing personal fulfillment for the sake of relationships. 01:34:50 David Goggins encourages open and honest conversations in relationships, advocating for individuals to reveal their true selves to others. He highlights the power of authenticity and the liberation it brings. 01:36:14 Goggins shares his personal journey of self-discovery and overcoming societal expectations, encouraging individuals to embrace their true selves, even if it means defying conventional norms. 01:37:41 David Goggins emphasizes the significance of self-awareness and confronting one's insecurities and fears, asserting that embracing the truth is the starting line for a fulfilling and empowered life. 01:41:58 David Goggins rejects external dependencies for motivation and emphasizes the importance of the unseen workâ€”personal struggles and triumphsâ€”as the true source of internal motivation and strength. 01:46:15 David Goggins emphasizes the importance of internal strength and the misconception that people have about his life. 01:47:14 Goggins discusses the capacity for everyone to build true confidence and the misunderstanding surrounding his approach. 01:48:37 The conversation shifts towards the process of building inner strength, focusing on actions and verbs rather than success. 01:53:49 The discussion touches on the frustration of being misunderstood, especially regarding Goggins' use of intense language, which he explains comes from a place of realness. 02:00:26 Goggins explains his approach to relationships, both with close ones and the general public, maintaining a boundary to preserve his ability to continue self-improvement. 02:04:10 Goggins describes his perspective on capped success, prioritizing continued self-improvement over financial success and recognizing the perishable nature of his unique willpower. 02:07:32 The conversation explores the perishable nature of the willpower Goggins possesses, emphasizing the importance of turning the mind's manifestations into concrete actions for lasting growth. 02:10:21 Daily actions are pre-planned, akin to an artist creating a masterpiece. Spending time alone without distractions allows the mind to reveal the next steps. Passion and determination stem from understanding oneself, not external influences. 02:15:37 Mastery of internal dialogue involves a two-way conversation, acknowledging both positive and negative voices. The symphony of voices within oneself determines the actions taken, leading to real-world outcomes. 02:20:02 Prioritizing learning how to fail is essential for eventual success. Acknowledging failures, enduring hardships, and practicing perseverance lay the foundation for achieving long-term goals. 02:25:47 The unconscious mind, the supercomputer, controls most aspects of behavior. Going inward involves confronting the deep, dark aspects of oneself, cleaning the internal "cupboards," and deliberate decision-making for meaningful actions. 02:30:30 Facing and embracing the hardships of the "dungeon," the uncomfortable and scary place in our minds, is crucial for growth. Confronting and cleaning out our deepest fears is essential to becoming the person we're meant to be. 02:32:54 Life is a continuous test, and challenges arise when we least expect them. Going inward, acknowledging flaws, and actively working on self-improvement are vital to passing life's tests and fulfilling our purpose. 02:34:46 David Goggins emphasizes the importance of authenticity and brutal honesty in personal growth. Sharing one's struggles and vulnerabilities not only aids personal development but also inspires others to confront their own challenges. 02:35:45 Andrew Huberman expresses gratitude for David Goggins' openness and authenticity. Goggins' willingness to share his journey lights the path for others, encouraging them to face their challenges and strive for personal growth.

I have the same problem with ADHD - I had great success by first creating a META framework structured by Purpose X Solution = Utility to learn better. I came to the realization that everything must have a purpose. The purpose defines the solution and ADHD people are generally performance oriented. The usefulness of the information MUST be specific.  Once the utility for my brain has been clearly defined, the brain begins to connect the information on a meta level. Everything goes faster. It's like running.  I learned that ADHD is a new generation brain. THE INFORMATION IS NOT STRUCTURED ENOUGH FOR ADHD. PROCEDURAL IS A â€œPAINâ€ FOR ADHD.  ADHD IS LIKE A QUANTUM OF BRAIN. THE LEARNING METHOD IS CENTRAL! META IS KEY. ELON MUSK ALSO MAY ALSO HAVE ADHD. IT'S THE FRAMEWORK WHAT MAKES IT DIFFERENT. I WAS IDENTIFIED WITH ADHD WHEN I WAS 5 YEARS OLD.  When I was a child, 10 to 20 mg of Ritalin in the morning improved my concentration - I was a little calmer mentally.

Goggins has changed the trajectory of my life. I was in my late 20s and had no direction to aim at in life - in conjunction of losing my long time girlfriend. Through difficult times, his voice rose up and invaded my ears 24/7. I changed my life around and pushed myself to achieve things beyond my wildest dreams. Itâ€™s been 8 years since I discovered Goggins and I continue to this day to extract knowledge, wisdom and of course motivation from David Goggins.

I have been following Goggins for a long time. After this program, my opinion became clearer. Goggins cannot let go. That discovery of the mid cortex touched upon an interesting point in terms of explaining the will, but I do not think that human thoughts are greatly affected by only one factor. This is the product of a collective brain structure. David's Regarding the issue, David has internalized the troubles he has experienced and fixed his awareness so much that there is no turning back for him. At the same time, the character and personality of a 40-year-old person who has done this job at a very late age, which is considered very rare, now reaches an unshakable stability, not like the age between 15 and 23. That's why This is a life mentality specific to Goggins personally, but of course, their alternating ways may appeal to us. Another issue I wonder about is the mid cortex. I know from my own experience that if I were to actually do something that I had never wanted to do before and had never done before, If I decide, I will do it. I don't think it depends on the size or smallness of that cortex.

Dr. Huberman, I have a question about your thoughts from your highly motivated life of purpose plus you are clearly connected to many people and it takes time and effort to maintain those relationships. You also appear to have a variety of wellness practices. You talk about sleep, you talk about exercise and getting sunlight. My question has to do with time. How are you choosing to balance these things and do you really think that happiness is less admirable than pursuing a goal? I hope il not sounding defensive but years ago I didnâ€™t have peace, I was highly motivated and tried very hard toward school and then professional goals which cost me lots of things I wish I had back now, 20 years later. I gained weight due to lack of sleep, chronic stress and accidentally over eating. I tried to make my marriage work in the off hours. I donâ€™t care to try to be extraordinary now other than I want to be living and caring. My purpose is not trying to build a career. Iâ€™m not struggling against sticky body hating it every day. I donâ€™t think I know more but I do believe my life is better with balance. Iâ€™m happy to get 8 hours of sleep. I am happy to make time to eat healthy food. Iâ€™m curious how you balance this. Iâ€™m not upset about normal anymore. I want to maximize my 9-10 hours of work and I want to focus on my family. I hope to get another chance of partnership and Iâ€™m going to focus on it kids than 2-3 hours a day. Iâ€™m curious how YOU combine David Goggins thoughts with the work Arther Brooks has done or your excellent podcast recently with Adam Grant. Again, Iâ€™m very inspired by David Goggins and am grateful for his example and I fully agree that the only thing that builds greatness or purpose is hard work and dedication. I just donâ€™t want a life with one thing - I donâ€™t want to feel like Iâ€™ve wasted my time and my life. This is why I love your podcast. I want to maximize my life, I just want more than work or pursuit of a single goal. And I donâ€™t want to have my family or a prospective partner have to fit into my life. Iâ€™d like to have time to invest in others and that only comes by forgoing something because like you said on the podcast, there isnâ€™t enough time to do it all. And maybe for you your passion and purpose is your work. I think itâ€™s totally reasonable for people to be ok without being extraordinary because of the time cost. Itâ€™s ok to have the time to give casual I tera too a time. Itâ€™s ok to stop and chat with the older person in the checkout. Â @WingedmagicianÂ  It's about accepting the suck. Once accepted, it doesn't matter whether you know what motivation means or not. You accepted the suck and you'll do it regardless of whether it will suck. Aka you will just do it. A lot of motivation/discipline techniques are about trying to circumvent the fact that it will suck (or sometimes they acknowledge it in part and will circumvent it in part). Once one accepts that it will suck, there is no more question on "how should I be motivated?" You're already motivated, because you accept the suck and you will do it. There's nothing more to it.

Learn the whole concept and dissect the concept to understand it more precisely. * There is No PASSION, HAPPINESS, or MOTIVATION in doing things. Life Sucks. JUST DO IT!  * People know what to do but the friction in doing sums up Laziness * Anterior-mid singular cortex - Part of the brain that gets bigger as you do the resistive & challenging things. But it shrinks if you don't do so! * There is No LIFE-HACK. Just do it!! Don't overthink. DO IT!! * Self Inspire & Self Motivate yourself, don't try to please people! * Don't get comfy. STAY HARD!  * When you start doing something tough, an inner negative voice comes and shouts at you to stop & relax and rest. Do listen to it, instead, develop another voice that inspires you! * 2 important things -1) Go Inward (Internal Dialogue) 2) Action (DO it) * Unconscious Mind -> Supercomputer of ourselves. Go inward and explore it!!  STAY HARD!  JUST DO IT!

He was the 36th African-American man to become a Navy SEAL.""By 2005, Goggins had put much of his weight back on from powerlifting. That all changed, again, in June 2005 when 19 service members, including many of Gogginsâ€™ friends, were killed during Operation Red Wings. (See sidebar.)  In their honor, Goggins wanted to raise money for the Special Operations Warrior Foundation, an organization that provides scholarships and counseling for children of fallen special operators. The only way he knew how to do that was by making himself â€œuncomfortable.â€  â€œI Google searched the 10 hardest events in the world,â€ Goggins said. â€œAnd what came up was a race called the Badwater 135.â€  At the time, Goggins said he didnâ€™t know anything about the â€œultra world.â€ He thought the Badwater Ultramarathon, a 135-mile race from Californiaâ€™s Death Valley to Mount Whitney, was a stage race where participants ran 135 miles over a few days â€” not 48 hours. To participate, athletes must have completed at least one ultramarathon.   â€œI called the [Badwater] race director on a Wednesday and participated in the San Diego One Day that Saturday,â€ Goggins said. â€œHe said if I could complete it in 24 hours, I was in.â€  The San Diego One Day is a 100-mile ultramarathon. Goggins said, at the time, he had never even run a marathon. He said he was confident that his mind would let him finish the race, but he didnâ€™t know how bad his body would â€œget destroyed.â€ During the 24-hour race, Goggins suffered broken metatarsals in both feet and shin splints. He said he was urinating blood at mile 70.   â€œI also shit on myself twice,â€ Goggins said. â€œIt was a bad day.â€  However, Goggins persevered and finished the race in about 19 hours."

Every day, I struggle. I know discipline is the key to freedom. I know discipline is the one choice i need to make in order to change myself and my life. My inner dialog is a battle that saps me of energy. My voice of reason in my head is relentless. I know better. I know what i need to do, but I fail at maintaining discipline. I lose track of my goals. I can't stay dedicated. I suffer because I know better and can't live up to my own standard of being. Every day is a battle of will I feel I continuously lose. I do not have sympathy for myself because it is weak and I can't afford it. Not when I am as low as I am. I can not justify my own weakness to myself. I can not give in to pity. Most days, I feel I wake up and go to war. A war between my external lifestyle and my internal truth. I do not know how to let my voice of reason win, to let discipline win. I do not know how to grow.

This podcast put into words something I've been grappling with for a while. Everywhere we look we see "stop being so hard on yourself." I went to therapy because I felt overweight, lazy, depressed, and directionless. The therapist said look at your life, you have a good job, a house, you have so many good things, so stop being hard on yourself, treat yourself, be kind to yourself, blah blah blah. Work to silence this part of yourself, and you'll be happy. No friction needed. So I stopped being hard on myself, stopped criticizing myself, I started following my base wants and desires. At first I had a little bit of positive feelings, but in the long run, I've turned into an even more overweight, lazy, depressed, directionless lump. I stopped thinking about myself and my life, stopped pushing myself. It's like I dissociated into a mildly pleasant frictionless life. I have no purpose, no meaning, no goals, no anything but go to work, eat the easiest meals, watch TV, look at my phone, and waste my money on junk. I'm sure my capitalist society loves me for it--thinks I'm perfect just like this--but I hate it. I hate myself and the life I've created. All in the spirit of not being hard on myself. All in the spirit of "give yourself some grace," as my therapist loved to put it. I'm not a piece of shit, but I sure have been acting like one, and I'm done.

Â @mitalgandecha3041Â  this is great to hear! I am a child of immigrants so it was a struggle trying to do all of this in a predominantly English speaking nation. I was learning how to speak English (thanks sesame Street) and going to speech classes, translating immigration papers to my family while also teaching them how to read in English, while helping my brother and helping with illegal under the table work. None of it was easy, and it's honestly refreshing hearing Goggins talk about it because I absolutely do feel crazy sometimes for how hard I am on myself because of where I came from. I felt crazy switching careers after dedicating a lot of time to college and HATING my career choice. I was actually happy in the service industry and around blue collar workers because they're real people. They know who they are, and there's nothing fake about them. It's refreshing to hear on a mainstream podcast about how valuable that is, because I was made to feel like a loser by college "elites" for being comfortable about that chaos. I've been told that I am hard to "deal with" because I do need my alone time. I need to decompress and my decompression is not in front of the t.v watching Netflix. My decompression is "fuck this, I'm going to Tahoe and hiking until I puke". Sorry to ramble on, but it's just nice to hear lol.
